I now reveal the entire mechanism in one phrase:
Body and mind are both fire and medicine.

When body and mind are settled, the mysterious aperture opens,
Essence, qi, and spirit naturally merge in emptiness.
After three hundred days, the fetal spirit sheds its husk,
Turning the body, it shatters the Great Void.

*Two Songs of the Mysterious Principle*

Though the Supreme Dao has no fixed abode,
It still relies on a master to transmit its rules.
Zhun and Meng take their images from dawn and dusk,
Fu and Gou borrow winter and summer, calling them Zi and Wu.

Advance the fire within nothingness to refine the Great Elixir,
Set the furnace and stabilize the cauldron to seek true earth.
Body, mind, and intent—three households united,
Lead, mercury, silver, and cinnabar share one origin.

Additions and subtractions follow the poem’s order,
Guarding the city, I distinguish host and guest.

The Red Child of South Mountain rides the Azure Dragon,
The Metal Elder of North Sea mounts the White Tiger.
These two medicines blend in perfect fusion,
A pair of tortoise and serpent naturally inhale and exhale.

Directly transcending the actual to return to the Great Vehicle,
Sudden enlightenment and perfect penetration are no small aid.
The secret meeting of the true mechanism is inherently natural—
Pity those petty methods that vainly prop themselves up.
With clever tongues and eloquent speech they boast of skill,
Arrogant in qi and haughty in heart—who dares challenge them?
Before learning to settle the mind into profound darkness,
Why trouble oneself with lofty aspirations in the garden’s walls?

Beginners naturally refuse to seek a master,
Yet in old age, having achieved nothing, they endure suffering.
Accumulating merit and piling up deeds to fill three thousand,
They reflect inward and turn their light back to exhaust the two and five.
The fire rises in the east as the tiger roars in the wind,
The dragon moves through rain, sweeping dust at the western extreme.
Commanding thunder and lightning, they employ the celestial stems,
Aiding the upright and expelling evil, the Dark Warrior takes its task.

The Enchanting Maiden has just left the Purple Ultimate Palace,
The Metal Elder has already arrived at the Vermilion Mound.
Within the furnace, the great medicine forms as a single pill,
In the chamber, the fetal immortal dances in triple rhythm.
The four images and five phases all harmonize,
The nine returns and seven reversals complete their universal work.

The bright toad emerges from its hermitage,
Its radiant light filling the vast universe.
To govern people and serve Heaven, nothing surpasses frugality—
Frugality is called the weighty accumulation of virtue.
The nature of Heaven is vast, yet it deeply examines the roots of dust,
The paths of principle are many, yet they increase karmic consciousness.
A heart bright with wisdom is no match for simplicity,
Grand eloquence and lofty discourse vie in vain with silence.

Cut off thoughts, forget schemes, and be free of right and wrong,
Conceal brilliance, contain splendor, and distance yourself from sound and color.
With few desires and plain flavors, good roots reach fulfillment,
Reducing affairs and simplifying ties, the root of virtue is planted.
A single thought fuses with the myriad voids, all clarified,
The three minds are refined, and all conditions cease.

Carefully observe the books of the sages of the Three Teachings—
The word "cessation" is the simplest and most direct.
If you cultivate effort on cessation,
To become Buddha or immortal requires no labor.
Cessation of conditions reveals the root—Chan’s mechanism,
Cessation of the heart illuminates principle—Confucianism’s ultimate.
Cessation of breath congeals spirit—Daoism’s mystery,
These three cessations support one another, and nothing is not overcome.

I speak to Zhitang and Tian Jiaochan:
Ultimately, one’s own mind is the rule and measure.

*Song of Nature and Principle*

The Two Modes first divided into the Three Ultimates,
Qian is upright and steadfast, Kun opens and closes.
Between Heaven and Earth lies the Mysterious Female’s gate,
The more it moves, the more it emerges; the more it is still, the more it enters.
The orthodox transmission of the Dao points to the return,
Confucius taught Zengzi, Zengzi taught Ziyu.
Wind follows the tiger as clouds follow the dragon,
Fire seeks dryness as water flows to moisture.

To harmonize and investigate things follows a proper order,
To enter sagehood and transcend the ordinary has no steps.
The noble person dwells in ease to await destiny,
Inwardly examining and finding no fault, what worry or sorrow remains?
To extend application and clarify the mechanisms of life and death,
Preserving the body ultimately depends on the hibernation of dragon and serpent.

Turn the light back to illuminate the dreamlike body,
Directly overturn the old volumes of scripture.
Polish away the dust and scrape off the grime to sever the roots of dust,
Release burdens and purify the heart, free from defiling habits.
Settle the mind into subtlety, and through resonance, it penetrates—
The ten thousand miles of the Yangtze River are swallowed in a single gulp.
Why need the Qian cauldron to refine golden essence?
No need for the Kun furnace to simmer jade nectar.

Thoroughly penetrating before Fuxi drew the trigrams,
The world is gathered and hidden within a millet grain.

*Song of Fire Phases*

To forge the mysterious within the mysterious, one must be vigilant in solitude,
The work of vigilance in solitude lies in the mechanism of the eye.
Sever all ties to sensory dust, free from slander or disgrace,
The square inch of the heart becomes clear and empty, gleaming like jade.
Push emptiness to its utmost, guard stillness with sincerity,
Within stillness, a single movement—yang returns.
The first nine: the hidden dragon must be restrained,
Advance to the "seeing dragon" but do not rush too quickly.

As soon as "vigilant and tireless" shines within,
It may leap or rest in the abyss—this is the time of bathing.
The nine five: the flying dragon achieves transformation and nurturing,
Yang at its peak, yin arises—one must retreat.
Guard against the subtle and block the gradual at Kun’s initial six,
Retreat to "upright and square," metal and wood conjoin.
The six three: do not be honored with emolument,
After "tying the sack," the divine elixir ripens.
If you encounter wild battles, restrain your ambition,
Yin eroded, yang pure—the fire phase is complete.

A single precious pearl is swallowed into the belly,
Becoming a complete immortal and celestial kin.
One husband and one wife ever in harmony,
The three pairs and three oddities follow in timely pursuit.
The Plain Girl and Azure Lad rest together,
Black mercury and red lead naturally gather.
The void constructs a dwelling of non-action,
This master is truly extraordinary.

Mountains conceal clouds, Heaven and Earth grow solemn,
The radiant toad’s light illuminates the empty valley.

*Song of Dragon and Tiger with Preface*

Dragon and tiger are alternate names for yin and yang.
The transformations of yin and yang are wondrous and unfathomable,
Thus they are symbolized by dragon and tiger.
The *Appended Judgments* of the *Book of Changes* says:
"One yin and one yang are called the Dao; yin and yang unfathomable are called spirit."
The alchemical texts say: "Partial yin or partial yang is called illness."
Yin and yang are the movement and stillness of the Great Ultimate.
Divided into two, the clear ascends and the turbid sinks;
Vast as Heaven and Earth, small as all things,
All receive the two qi of yin and yang and take form and name.
Thus, between the covering and bearing,
From the most minute to the most vast,
Nothing lies outside the course of yin and yang.

The alchemical classics and philosophical texts,
With their myriad alternate names,
Do not exceed the two words yin and yang.
The immortals of past ages,
Using metaphors and establishing symbols,
Compared them to dragon and tiger,
So that students could easily grasp the pattern and succeed.

The images of dragon and tiger,
Endlessly transforming, wondrous and inexhaustible,
Are thus compared to medicines,
Established as the furnace and cauldron,
Operated as fire phases,
Compared to kan and li,
Borrowed as metal and wood,
Named as male and female,
Paired as husband and wife.
These alternate names all express the wondrous functions of dragon and tiger.

By their numinous responsiveness, they are called medicines;
By their ability to form things, they are called furnace and cauldron;
By their transformations, they are called fire phases;
By their mutual assistance, they are called kan and li;
By their hardness and straightness, they are called metal and wood;
By their rising and sinking, they are called male and female;
By their wondrous union, they are called husband and wife.
Without dragon and tiger, how could these be fully expressed?

The *Wenyan* says: "Clouds follow the dragon, wind follows the tiger; when the sage arises, the myriad things observe."
This elucidates the virtue of Qian’s nine five.
Thus, the wondrousness of dragon and tiger—
Without divine virtue and sagely achievement, how could one be worthy of them?

Turning inward to seek, this is the nature of one’s feelings and essence;
Transforming and cultivating them, this is body and mind, soul and spirit, essence and qi.
Extending and practicing this, it is the gate of the Mysterious Female, the mechanism of opening and closing.

The *Taishang* says: "The valley spirit does not die—this is called the Mysterious Female. The gate of the Mysterious Female is called the root of Heaven and Earth." Subtly continuous, as if present—its use is inexhaustible.

The *Yi* says: "Closing the door is called Kun; opening the door is called Qian. One closing and one opening is called change; ceaseless coming and going is called penetration."

The *Elixir Scripture* says: "Exhaling connects to the root of Heaven; inhaling connects to the root of Earth—this is the mechanism of Qian and Kun’s opening and closing. Exhaling, the dragon hums and clouds arise; inhaling, the tiger roars and wind is born—this is one closing and one opening called change. Wind and clouds respond and unite, transforming to generate the golden liquid—this is ceaseless coming and going called penetration. The golden liquid returns, congealing into the Great Elixir, hence provisionally named the Dragon-Tiger Great Elixir. Gathering and ingesting it, one attains longevity and enduring vision—this so-called breathing is not that of mouth and nose. The true mechanism’s wondrous response is the gate of one emergence and one entry. If you can penetrate this, the Dragon-Tiger Elixir will form, and immortality may be hoped for.

Those who cultivate the truth, if they can thoroughly master and fully penetrate the Dragon and Tiger, though the Way of true constancy is called most profound and subtle, how could they fear failure? As for planting good roots, establishing virtue’s foundation, and nurturing the sacred embryo, none have succeeded without clarifying the Dragon and Tiger.

Master Ziyang said: "Gathering body and mind is called subduing the Dragon and Tiger. When the mind is unmoving, the dragon hums; when the body is unmoving, the tiger roars. The dragon’s humming consolidates qi; the tiger’s roaring congeals essence. When primordial essence congeals, it suffices to preserve form; when primordial qi is consolidated, it suffices to concentrate spirit. When form and spirit are both wondrous, they unite with the Dao in truth—thus the immortal’s task is complete. If not one of utmost spirit in the world, who could attain this?"

Zhao Shuzhai, a native of ancient Hangzhou, served as a eunuch in his youth, holding the office of palace attendant. Through the turning of Qian and the revolving of Kun, he saw through the illusions of floating life, thus abandoning profit and renouncing fame to seek the essentials of the Dao. Though he mingled in the red dust, his heart dwelled in the realm of mystery—a true transcender of worldly affairs. Desiring to blend and congeal spirit, he focused his mind on the Dragon and Tiger. One day, he brought this diagram to me, asking for an inscription. I declined, but he insisted, so I took up my brush to fulfill my duty.

I said to him: "The ancients established images based on the Dao; you now establish words based on images. Zhao Shuzhai, the key lies in sharpening your discernment, observing the teachings’ precision, and not mistaking the fixed pole star. If you can grasp the meaning through words and comprehend the intent through the diagram, you will know that the true Dragon and true Tiger are not on paper but within yourself. When words and images are both forgotten, virtue and the Dao are complete."

Ah! The true Dragon and true Tiger are not hard to find—just draw forth yang to supplement yin. With the Four Virtues circulating Qian without cease, hidden flight and manifest leaping are all at the heart’s command. Though it begins on level ground, it surges like waves in the blue sky, resounding like thunder.

Strive on, strive on!

*Song:*
...

The true Dragon and true Tiger originally have no form—
who then devised a model to transmit this pattern?
If you grasp them within the formless,
you fall into rigid duality, forever reckless and wild.

Green and white, too distinct and clear—
this is but waves rising without wind.
If one would know the true Dragon and Tiger,
they belong neither to being nor non-being, nor to the axis of zi and wu.
Do not confuse the two and swallow them whole;
simply reverse the count of the Five Phases.
Root and sprout dwell in the Palace of Great Mystery,
while creation unfolds in the Crimson Numinous Treasury.
Though their operation has a guiding principle,
in truth, the numinous void has no fixed abode.
A single great Dao demands the heart’s penetration;
a trace of divine mechanism is not seen by the eye.
Suddenly, the crown gate opens—
you discern that Wood and Metal share one mother.
Lofty, beyond the highest peak, the Big Dipper’s handle is broken;
bright, the Silver River’s ladle pours forth.
Clouds rise and mists form through Ding’s power;
lightning flashes and thunder is driven by the Dark Warrior’s might.
In an instant, Heaven and Earth unite;
in a moment, Kan and Li are mended.
The Tiger stirs a pure breeze from water’s depths;
the Dragon descends sweet rain from fire’s midst.
Thunder moves, rain falls, the world is at peace—
the Dragon’s virtue circulates Qian, its merit universally bestowed.

People say six dragons bear the heavens,
but who knows the one Dragon is the true sovereign?
People say five tigers pierce the Mysterious Pass,
but who knows the one Tiger arises from true earth?
When you grasp that Dragon and Tiger are ever in harmony,
you will see the Tortoise and Serpent mutually devour and disgorge.

The sage sets forth images to point to the snare’s trace;
beyond images, clear words become mere chatter.
Beyond words, you must fathom the ancestral intent—
in truth, the Great Ultimate was originally without mark.
To grasp the meaning and forget the image is not yet exceptional;
only when meaning too is forgotten do you reach the ultimate norm.

I bow to Zhao Shuzhai, the recluse—
having thoroughly overturned all, his study of the mysteries is complete.

*Song of No-One:*
The Dao, fundamentally formless, gives birth to the Great Ultimate;
the Great Ultimate transforms, and first there is One.
One divides into Two, Two begets Three—
from this arise the Four Images and Five Phases.
No-One is the root of Heaven and Earth;
the Mysterious Teaching’s One is the gate of all wonders.
Change begins within the One to unfold creation;
the human heart’s One governs the warp of the cosmos.
Heaven attains One and is clear; Earth attains One and is tranquil;
valleys attain it and are full; spirits attain it and are numinous.
Things attain it and are completed; people attain it and live;
lords and kings attain it, and the world is upright.
Chan transmits the true Dharma within the One;
Confucianism opens and closes from the One character.
Laozi expounded true constancy through the One;
Zengzi’s “only One” is wondrous beyond measure.
The Dao has Three Vehicles, Chan five schools—
yet in the end, a thousand lamps share one light.
Embrace the Origin, guard the One, and the Mysterious Aperture opens;
be precise, be one, and the Sage’s Teaching is illuminated.
The True One of Great Mystery is the Gate of Returning to Life—
know that the One is the true constant Dao.
Do not say that attaining the One completes all things;
attain the One, hold to the One, and never lose it.
When the One penetrates all, Heaven’s principle is clear—
yet the myriad methods returning to One are not yet extraordinary.
At first, the One and the formless give birth to the myriad existents;
existence and non-existence mutually sustain and endure.
If you can return the myriad existents to the formless One,
only then will you face south and behold the Northern Dipper.
At this point, having attained the One, you must forget the One—
then you may emerge and submerge with the primordial transformation.
If you cling to the One and cannot forget,
you are like a foolish cat guarding an empty burrow.
The Three and Five merge into One, returning to the void;
after returning to the void, the void too vanishes.
When non-void is no more, all is profoundly still—
the Western barbarian’s beard and whiskers are gone.
People today call non-being “non-being,”
wandering in boundless emptiness, treading perilous paths.
People today call the One “the One,”
stubbornly clinging, wasting effort in vain.
If you can grasp the non-being that is not nothingness,
then in guarding the One, you will know the One is no-One.
The two words “One” and “non-being” are both overturned—
Master No-One has completed the great task.

*Song of Embracing the One:*
The Non-Ultimate becomes the Great Ultimate;
the Great Ultimate spreads its wonders beginning with the One.
One divides into Two, giving birth to yin and yang—
the myriad kinds and Three Powers arise from this.
Originally, the true One is utterly void and numinous,
unchanging from ancient times to the present.
Only because essence takes form and spirit awakens to knowing
do the mechanisms of good and evil, causes and conditions, diverge.
Following emotions and chasing illusions, brambles grow thick;
fragrance, flavor, color, and sound all delude and confuse.
If you can investigate the root and origin through the One,
returning to the origin and restoring the fundamental requires no effort.
One man and one woman unite in the center’s embrace—
three daughters and three sons cannot be contained within.
The Three Primes and Eight Trigrams meet in ren;
the Four Images and Five Phases return to utmost stillness.
Suddenly, the crown gate is broken open—
flashing golden light fills the spirit chamber.
The valley of the formless naturally opens;
the Gate of the Mysterious Female opens and closes of itself.
The return of the one yang is wondrous beyond measure;
the Four Virtues circulate Qian without cease.
Vast qi congeals the spirit in profound obscurity,
emerging into existence, entering into non-existence, in the realm of the indistinct.
What is the master within?
It is the original possession of the enlightened gentleman.

*Song of the Wisdom Sword:*
Since the perfected one transmitted the sword’s secret,
the true command is fully raised, resolute and decisive.
If someone asks me to reveal its trace and origin,
I say it is no ordinary iron.
This lump of iron
emerges from the kun direction;
once it enters my hand, it becomes majestic.
Fiercely refined in fire upon fire,
through a hundredfold refinement, it becomes steel.

You who study the Dao, know this secret—
the yang spirit’s might destroys yin demons.
Its divine power and wondrous use are truly immeasurable;
I now lay bare its workings for you.
I tell you,
revealing Heaven’s mechanism:
begin when the one yang returns.
First command the six jia to fan the furnace bellows;
then the six ding wield the pincers and hammer.
When the firing is complete, the sword is forged—
at first, it gleams like lightning.
Wielded horizontally, a chilling wind arises;
plunged upright, a bright moon appears.
The bright moon appears,
radiant light shines—
flashing to earth, illuminating the sky, gods and ghosts lament.
It stirs the turbid and lifts the pure, sweeping away evil and filth,
slaying dragons, beheading tigers, annihilating serpents and oysters.
The six thieves perish, the three corpses are severed—
ties are cut, thoughts cast off, the net of emotions is torn.
Where the divine blade points, mountains crumble—
the demon kings of the three realms are all destroyed.
This precious sword
is originally formless;
its divine power forces it to be named.
To study the Dao and cultivate the real, rely on this sword—
without this sword, the Dao is hard to achieve.
It opens primordial chaos, orders Heaven and Earth—
dissolving obstacles, transforming dust, nothing is beyond its reach.
If someone asks to borrow it and see,
I will take it up and show you—do you understand?

**"Song of Drawing the Crooked Back to the Straight"**

The Dao arises from emptiness, birthing the One Qi—
who imposed names to divide the Five Ultimates?
The One Qi splits, giving rise to the Two Modes:
pure ascends, turbid descends, forming heaven and earth.
Yin and yang weave like a flying shuttle,
while Qian and Kun open and close like bellows.
The Two Modes wondrously unite to form the Three Powers,
and the seven apertures carved open birth the ten thousand kinds.
The true essence of the Limitless refines the primordial chaos—
in daily use, it is ever-present, nothing excluded.
The hundred thousand transformations of life and change
all unfold within this very skin-sack.
If you truly seek the root and origin,
the Four Symbols and Five Phases are already complete.
Reverse the three by day and night, undivided in purpose—
cut off profit at its source, and merit multiplies a hundredfold.
Break through the Pass of Essence and the Pass of Qi,
silently fathoming the celestial and earthly melodies.
Every step aligns with the compass and square,
every aperture shines unimpeded.
If you possess eyes within this,
you merge the two into one.
Lift your head—Mount Sumeru topples;
take a step—the Mysterious Wondrous Camp collapses.
Grasp this single principle to expound the true source,
and the myriad differences converge in the right stream.
Refine the yang spirit to transcend the yang spirit,
rising from the realm of form to the formless realm.

Now I see those who cultivate today—
most fabricate demons and conjure aberrations.
Their qi lofty and overbearing, they scorn their peers,
flaunting wit and boasting of their own mastery.
Sharp in debate, they feign cleverness,
riding high on empty talk, parading wisdom.
Novices are deceived, the learned shun them—
all for show, heedless of future calamity.
Chattering endlessly before others,
like selling water by the riverbank.
Fires of anger flare from stray thoughts,
the mind narrows, chasing circumstances.
Dissipating spirit in vain exertion,
feverishly flailing in chaos.
Refining essence and moving qi—labor wasted;
counting breaths and massaging—mere fleeting pleasure.
Drowsiness and distraction defy control—
if not dull, then scattered—what recourse?
Spirit wanes, qi scatters—how to heal?
Marrow exhausted, form emaciated—regret comes too late.
If you seek the true Dao to escape delusion,
avoid repaying karmic debts.
Gather in your former reckless heart,
overturn your past arrogance.
Extend the heart of serving your father to serving your master,
and first uphold the precepts to receive the teaching.
Extend the heart of forgiving yourself to forgive others,
not blaming them, but bestowing goodness.
Not self-enlightened, yet perfecting enlightenment;
not self-aggrandizing, yet achieving greatness.
Without affairs, without desires, without knowledge—
discard excess, discard extravagance, discard excess.
Establish the foundation and begin with strict discipline,
refining through every encounter and circumstance.
Rely solely on lead and mercury as the elixir’s head—
do not mistake mud for treasure.
Moreover, the upper and lower must alternate in sequence,
not mistaking east and west for Zhen and Dui.
The exchanged pear and fire-date are not kidney and heart,
the wood-fluid and metal-essence are not liver and lung.
Do not cling to Pratyekabuddhas or Śrāvakas,
nor to views, knowledge, or learned explanations.
In the end, nurture the child within the nothingness—
the dhyāna heavens purified, free of the tiniest speck.
The mechanism of nine returns and seven reversals
lies neither within nor without.
The original true form is formless,
eternally luminous, never obscured.
Embrace the One and guard unity, enfolding all emptiness—
steadfast in purpose, diligent in practice, never lax.
Harmonize the Four Symbols, gather the Three Origins,
assemble the Five Phases, unite the Eight Trigrams.
Refine *geng* and temper *jia*, with withdrawals and additions,
knowing the advance and retreat of yang fire and yin tally.
In the stillness of emptiness, the mechanism turns—
in the indistinct and profound, creation revolves.
Two numinous beings enter the Central Palace,
a single golden light illumines all directions.
The Old Woman of Huang in the southwest,
beats the drum to wed the Ding Maiden of Nanling.
The Green-Clad Girl returns to her chamber,
the White-Headed Lord enters the house.
Husband and wife unite in yin and yang,
clouds and rain forget day and night.
Qi solidifies, essence congeals—forming the sacred embryo,
giving birth to a wondrous pearl, most rare.
Four-sided, it gleams with radiance,
eight-faced, flawlessly smooth.
This small round sphere—
ten thousand taels of gold could not match its worth.
I bow to all Quanzhen seekers—
remember the words spoken at Qing’an.
If you truly accept them here and now,
you grasp the very target.
But once the target is made—what then?
The Positionless True Person rides the crane’s carriage.

**Compiled by Disciple Sun’an Baochanzi Cai Zhiyi**

**Seventeen Poems on the Work of Cultivation**

**Initiating the Ninefold Returned Elixir**
To begin the ninefold returned elixir’s work,
know first the welling spring beneath the mountain’s base.
The furnace’s wondrous use relies on Kun’s earth,
the fire’s labor draws upon Xun’s wind.
Dui’s tiger and Zhen’s dragon just commingle,
Kan’s boy and Li’s girl then harmonize as one.
Once the four images return to center,
the mechanism of creation rests in me alone.

**Right: Arousing the Unenlightened**

**Gathering the Medicine**
Refining mercury and smelting lead—no fixed time,
the learner must seek within stillness to discern.
Guest-dust and desire may taint, yet the heart remains untouched;
when heavenly water first stirs, the spirit knows of itself.
With emotions stilled, gold returns to its nature’s root;
essence congeals, Kan departs to mend southern Li.
When these two numinous things unite,
yin exhausted and yang pure, the Dao may be attained.

**Right: Gathering the Medicine**

**Advancing the Fire**
Once heavenly water begins to flow,
true yang naturally returns in due season.
Samādhi fire arises from Li’s position,
a thunderclap resounds from Zhen’s palace.
Qi and spirit merge to form a numinous substance,
heart and breath interdepend to knit the sacred embryo.
Piercing the inner core’s subtle sign,
the three barriers and nine apertures open as one.

**Right: Advancing the Fire**

**Daily Practice**
True lead and true mercury—great elixir’s head,
gather them where formless form abides.
Acting and striving still bring encumbrance;
seeking nothing, clinging not, one knows no care.
Ever clear, ever still—the heart’s pearl appears,
forgetting things, forgetting schemes—the life-treasure circulates.
In movement and stillness, no obstruction,
where you stand is Penglai Isle.

**Right: Daily Use**

**Consolidating Form**
The Quanzhen’s wondrous principle is not hard to practice,
only fear following conditions, chasing sights and sounds.
Myriad illusions cannot invade when passions cease,
a single heart unstained—thoughts arise in peace.
Banish self and others to fulfill heaven’s principle,
grasp yin and yang to join in supreme harmony.
I tell the elixir-refining noble ones:
when sights and sounds leak not, nature shines complete.

**Right: Consolidating Form**

**Union**
The Dao of true constancy is not at all difficult,
it lies only in daily use, here and now.
One unites Qian and Kun, knowing opening and closing,
the two wheels of sun and moon cycle of themselves.
Returning to the root has its returning aperture,
restoring life has its restoring gate.
Treading the twofold subtle sign,
transcending the mundane, surpassing the sacred—ease itself.

**Right: Penetrating the Barrier**

**Entry and Exit**
The valley spirit never dies—this is the mysterious female,
the very mechanism of Qian and Kun’s opening and closing.
Coming and going without cease,
pushing and surging without fail.
The white-haired old master rides the dragon away,
the blue-eyed foreign lad mounts the tiger home.
Ask where the work’s completion is proven—
the moon’s light encircles heaven and earth.

**Right: Entry and Exit**

**Admonishing the Multitude**
Mouthing the three mysteries in vain boasting,
broad discourse and lofty talk only lead further astray.
Better to embody form to seek true reality,
than to squeeze the eyes and conjure empty flowers.
Following things leads ever to illusion’s end;
turning the head around, you arrive home at once.
Do not fault Qing’an for its blunt speech—
it pries open the heart’s aperture to leave no veil.

**Right: Admonishing the Multitude**

**Correcting Deviations**
Three thousand six hundred side doors,
those who cling to them grope in darkness within.
Each day they merely see with the heart’s eye—
when will they awaken to life’s return to the root?
Keen wit and exceptional talent—what need for the Dao?
Sharp wisdom and deep insight—no cause for discussion.
All forms, names, sounds, and appearances—
in the end, all are but toying with the spirit-soul.

**Right: Correcting Deviations**

**Confronting Demons**
How to forbid night’s drowsy stupor?
Ghostly faces and spirit-heads appear—what then?
Dullness and distraction arise from turbid qi,
thoughts’ discontinuity from excess yin.
When the tide comes, water reaches the shore;
when wind stills, the river’s heart knows no waves.
With nature still and passions void, the heart unmoved,
birth knows no dullness, sleep knows no demons.

**Right: Confronting Demons**

**Revealing the Correct**
The fire-tally is easy, the medicine not forced—
heavenly water rises like the ocean’s tide.
Know to gather the two kinds of mercury and lead,
casting off all desires and objects at once.
Overturning the myriad existences, the three primals unite;
refining all yin, the five qi pay homage.
After ten months, the embryo sheds its shell—elixir’s work complete,
the infant’s form appears to ascend the divine clouds.

**Right: Revealing the Correct**

**Harmonizing**
The great medicine of the three primals—mind, heart, body,
fixating on mind, heart, body binds one to dust.
Regulating breath requires regulating the true breath,
refining spirit requires refining the spiritless spirit.
Suddenly forgetting self and others, the three flowers gather,
fiercely relinquishing conditions, the five qi arrive.
Eightfold open, fourfold unobstructed,
at all times and places, the Quanzhen is revealed.

**Right: Harmonizing**

**Illuminating the Root**
The self arises from emptiness, yet forces a name—
with a name, the heart’s affairs become entangled.
Yin and yang wax and wane through past and present,
sun and moon rise and set, governing death and life.
If you can preserve constancy amid the flux,
you will know noon’s three watches.
Though worldly conduct relies on the master’s teaching,
the work of transcending the world must be self-realized.

**Right: Illuminating the Root**

**Forging the Sword**
The enlightened master teaches me to forge the spirit-blade,
relying wholly on yin and yang’s creative power.
Tempering Qian’s hardness, Kun serves as the forge,
blowing with Li’s fire, Xun becomes the wind.
Crafting dragon and elephant within the heart’s palace,
sweeping away demonic vapors with a marshal’s resolve.
Those who know this art of the Dao’s high adepts
casually cleave the vast emptiness itself.

**Right: Forging the Sword**

**The Toad’s Grotto**
The toad’s grotto—serene and secluded, the finest realm,
where the master, upside-down, makes his livelihood.
The jade furnace smelts the golden liquid,
the golden tripod simmers the white numinous sprout.
Turning the handle of the Dipper to revolve the heavens,
pushing the tally-fire to drive the thunder-chariot.
Once all barriers and locks are pierced,
freely navigate the Silver River on a sturdy raft.

**Right: The Toad’s Grotto**

**Qing’an Hermitage**
My hermitage is no ordinary retreat—
it does not permit casual visits from the common folk.
One wife, one husband can sustain life,
three boys, three girls form a perfect circle.
The inner world is vast indeed,
while the outer void is not so wide.
Ask the master what he is about—
he replies: "Face south and behold the Northern Dipper."

**Right: Qing’an Hermitage**

**Twelve Poems on True Joy**

Buddhas and immortals are all made by men,
yet how can they not know they wander lost?
If not for chasing fame and striving in calculation,
they would surely race after profit, toiling in haste.

Toiling ceaselessly to bear the weight of family,
hurrying endlessly to provide for wife and child.
Even if wealth and honor come, and the wife’s beauty shines,
when impermanence arrives, how can they follow you?
How much better to embrace the wondrous perfection of the True,
where true joy within the heart is known to none but oneself.
The elixir is refined not through refining but in non-refinement,
the Dao is enacted not through action but in non-action.
Still the thoughts, sever the ties to harmonize the ancestral qi,
forget hearing, forget seeing to nurture the infant within.
Once the foundation of the elixir is firmly laid,
five-colored radiance pierces through curtains and screens.
The furnace employs Kun, the crucible employs Qian,
delving into the subtlest principles, one becomes a transcendent.
It is nothing but subduing emotions to return to nature,
which is the refining and merging of mercury and lead.
When all scheming ceases, the elixir glows crimson,
when true stillness is preserved, the treasure hardens firm.
This is the method of withdrawal and addition—
no need for anxious questioning of mysteries.
The fire-tally is easy, the medicine not distant,
creation’s workings are like the great ocean’s tide.
The medicine is gathered only from within the void,
the fire-elixir burns wholly in stillness.
Nine and three converge, all conditions cease,
two and eight unite, the five qi pay homage.
When yin is exhausted and yang pure, the work is complete—
the True Person emerges to pay respects in the divine clouds.

The elixir is first refined by harmonizing qi and spirit,
Dharma-water is poured to kindle the fire of wisdom.
Three substances merge, three natures unite,
one yang revives as one yin dissipates.
The golden furnace stands upright, a thousand spirits gather,
the precious crucible’s work complete, ten thousand images pay homage.
When the medicine is perfected and the elixir formed, the spirit sheds its husk,
the numinous body emerges, naked and unadorned.

The supreme principle of the primordial is wondrous beyond fathoming:
lead arises in the West, mercury in the East.
Water and fire divide above and below,
the Mysterious Pass lies in the center.
To know the unknowable is true knowing,
to comprehend emptiness is true emptiness.
The meaning of being and non-being, of having and not-having—
like the sun’s crimson glow at the ocean’s depths.

Abiding in stillness, one accords with the true constant,
dissolving all yin to restore yang.
Within Kun, the Yellow Dame gives birth to the Crimson Child,
in Li, the Enchanted Maiden weds the Foolish Lad.
On the mountain’s peak, water descends and the Yellow Sprout grows,
beneath the earth, thunder rumbles and White Snow flies.
A thousand miles of silver rivers bear not a speck of dust,
the Golden Toad alone reveals its divine radiance.

The bewitching Young Girl burns to wed the Golden Elder,
all depends on the Yellow Dame’s matchmaking skill.
Once the couple meets,
their cloud-and-rain passions unite in harmony.
At leisure, they drink together in the Vermilion Mansion,
drunk, they sleep side by side in the Purple Ultimate Palace.
Evening joy, morning fear—such weighty bonds of love,
in a year’s time, a little child is born.

Within every person lies a husband and wife,
yet how foolish and deluded they remain!
They do not seek creation within,
but instead lay the elixir’s foundation without.
Falsely taking the Three Peaks’ art of bedroom techniques,
they counterfeit the marvel of Xuanyuan’s Nine Tripods.
Such bestial acts are hard to repent—
soon Lord Yama’s summons will arrive.

The husband and wife within the body I speak of to you:
a blue-clad maiden and a white-haired elder.
Metal’s nature and Wood’s essence unite,
black mercury and red lead naturally resonate.
Beneath moon and wind, the spirit roams in bliss,
clouds drift, rain falls—endless delight.
If you truly grasp these principles,
the true embryo coalesces as easily as turning a palm.

The Great Elixir of Nine Returns and Seven Reversions—
seekers must seek it within stillness.
If you grasp this subtle mechanism,
the two numinous substances will unite.
Three years’ creation is completed in an instant,
nine cycles’ work circles in a moment.
Then overturn the crucible and furnace—
the elixir’s light illuminates the four divine continents.

No written texts are established for transmission beyond the teachings,
for in each person’s portion, the original perfection is already complete.
The subtle breeze of the Mysterious gently purifies the three realms,
the moon of wisdom shines brightly, imprinting the hundred rivers.

The Three Gates of Tusita are but metaphors,
the single finger of the Heavenly Dragon is no true explanation.
Beyond the sound of thunder, messages are conveyed—
this is not Zhou Dunyi’s Supreme Ultimate circle.

**Four Conditions to Warn the World**

Body, mind, worldly affairs—four empty names,
how many deluded souls are ensnared by them?
Calamity arises only from grasping at power and profit,
the wheel of rebirth turns solely for love’s attachments.
To pacify the mind, sever all traces from the body’s movements,
in the world, forget scheming and let things take their course.
When encountering circumstances, always yield and comply—
thus the foundation of life is eternally firm, and nature perfectly luminous.

**Ode to the Gourd**

The numinous sprout’s seed is born of the primordial,
its stem firm, roots deep—such is the principle of nature.
Daily, it is nurtured with earth from Kun’s position,
timely, it is watered with springs from Kan’s midst.
Its blossoms open like white jade, radiant and lustrous,
its seeds form like yellow gold, round and firm.
When the work is complete, a single aperture opens atop—
within, a distinct Qian and Kun are revealed.

**The Heart-Mirror**

Gather Qian’s ore into Kun’s furnace,
the six directions and empty space become one mold.
When the Dharma-image is formed, it shines resplendent,
where mercury is polished, it gleams like jade.
Its radiance extends throughout the three thousand worlds,
its gathering returns to a single millet-grain pearl.
Lift it clearly, and the whole body appears—
yet one must shatter it to unite with the original pivot.

**For Fuan Hermitage: Pointing to the Mysterious Female**

The Mysterious Gate’s female portal is not hard to know—
gather body and mind, and turn inward.
When you grasp the principle of the Two Modes’ ebb and flow,
you will understand the qi’s coming and going.
Qian and Kun open and close without cease,
Li and Kan rise and sink, unite and part.
For Fuan Hermitage, I clearly point this out—
where thoughts return, the elixir’s foundation is laid.

**Matching the Rhymes of Weng’s Learning Record**

Hidden meanings probe the *Cantong Qi* with White Jade Toad,
only by exhausting principles does one become a transcendent.
Before the Supreme Ultimate gives rise to the Three and Five,
one vainly treads the eight thousand leagues to Penglai.
The Śākya family’s tradition relies on the ancestral seal,
the Fuxi lineage’s Dao must be transmitted heart-to-heart.
The jade terrace’s moon alone shines in the azure sky,
imprinting a thousand pools with the same perfect roundness.

**For Deng Yichan**

Chan, Confucianism, and the Perfect Real—
teachings establish three gates to guide later generations.
Śākya’s tradition stores emptiness, one must see nature,
Confucian scholars investigate things, they must preserve sincerity.
The Elixir Terrace retains a spark of fire,
the numinous palace melts away all dust.
When you grasp that the myriad differences return to one,
within and beyond the Terrace of Joy, spring reigns everywhere.

**Seven Poems on Self-Attainment**

Shatter the vast chaos’ aperture—
no Buddhas, no immortals remain.
It is neither a marvel beyond the heart,
nor a Chan phrase on the lips.
Days pass in carefree ease,
nights in unrestrained sleep.
Entrusting the body to the hidden, absolute realm,
all things are left to Heaven.

All conditioned dharmas,
every one, are but dust.

Pursue the principles of all things to their end,
lay down this heart and body.
Wherever you are, settle into meditative stillness,
following the times, delight in the true.
Often wield the marrow of the *Zhouyi*,
to rouse and awaken the worldly.
Having attained the wondrous subtlety of non-action,
you need not step beyond your door all day.

All karmic conditions are wholly severed,
Heaven’s principle naturally abides.
In daily use, Heaven’s movement is strong,
in the ordinary, Earth’s bearing is receptive.
Admonish your disciples at the gate,
return to life and revert to the root.
Break through every barrier and lock,
naturally merging into the Great Harmony.

Tortoise hair was always green,
the crane’s crown was ever red.
What can be spoken is not the eternal Dao,
external practices are but superficial work.
This child is truly of the creative process,
amidst the indistinct and profound.
Attaining stillness of body and mind,
concentrate the spirit, solidify the essence.

The body at leisure transcends the leaky,
the heart in quiescence realizes non-arising.
Sun and moon come and go as ever,
Heaven and Earth change at will.
Vast and unobstructed,
the great radiance alone shines forth.

In daily life, nothing else matters,
but to uphold one’s own sincerity.
In stillness, regulate the breath,
in movement, follow human feelings.
Conceal virtue to blend with the common,
embrace refinement without display.
In the place of true leisure and joy,
ever still and ever pure.
Embrace nameless simplicity in stillness,
worldly passions cannot intrude.

Mercury and lead melt into powder,
tiles and stones transform into gold.
Yearning to see the faces of Fuxi and the Yellow Emperor,
to harmonize the hearts of Śākya, Laozi, and Confucius.
Suddenly empty, transcending the actual,
no past, no present.

**Inscribed on My Portrait**
A sallow-faced, emaciated fellow—
what’s so extraordinary about that?
Clearly, those are but borrowed eyes,
yet you claim all hearing and knowing are cut off.
Having seen through the three thousand dharmas,
I’ve harmonized the teachings of seventeen masters.
Bowing my head, hands clasped—
all pretenses are utterly exposed.

**Two Poems on the Mirror and Lamp**
The precious mirror is originally formless,
the transmitted lamp emits wisdom’s light.
True Suchness is inherently pure,
the Dharma-body fundamentally radiant.
The golden crucible burns with true fire,
the flowery pond bathes in the great sun.
Within this, the essential meaning
never departs from the central yellow.

In the quiet chamber, the heart-mirror opens,
in the empty hall, the wisdom-lamp is trimmed.
Without, it shines brightly,
within, it glows resplendently.
A grain of millet appears in the light,
the silver toad is clear in the water’s depths.
Suspended in the golden crucible,
a single grain of the great elixir congeals.

**Two Poems on the Lotus Root**
A singular numinous sprout,
unlike all others.
The Dharma-body is inherently immaculate,
the true nature originally flawless.
Outwardly, every part is curved,
within, every aperture is connected.
Mired in mud, it cannot be submerged,
bursting forth in crimson across the pond.

I am a seed of purity and emptiness,
flawless through the ages.
Weary of the clutter of fame and profit,
I hide deep in the mud.
Ever harboring the intent to aid others,
constantly holding a heart of self-restraint.
So many who dredge and strain—
who among them is a true kindred spirit?

**Two Poems on the Hermitage**
Having chosen the most empty and formless ground,
karmic conditions reside in the Jade Capital.
Lay the foundation firmly,
set the crucible level.
Erect a pillar as tall as Mount Sumeru,
place the crossbeam of the Supreme Ultimate.
The blue sky serves as the roof,
the hermit delights in non-arising.

The earth is leveled as if carved,
the hermitage’s foundation is completed today.
The incoming mountain enters from the south,
the departing water flows west.
Doors and windows are all unobstructed,
the lattice panes are thoroughly bright.
Who is the hermit’s companion?
The white moon and the clear wind.

*End of Scroll Five of the* Zhonghe Collection
*Scroll Six of the* Zhonghe Collection *begins*

**Six Lyrics to "Spring in the Garden of Seepage"**
*Composed by Li Daochun Yuan-su of Jingchan of Duliang Hermitage*
*Compiled by Disciple Sunchan Baochanzi Cai Zhi-yi*

**I**
To meet true transmission is to know where to begin—
success is not difficult.
Wait for the moment *gui* is born:
draw forth lead, add mercury,
fire must not be too dry,
water must not be allowed to chill.
Stir the *xun* wind,
fan open the furnace-bellows—
martial refinement and literary simmering are no trifling matter.
Within the golden crucible,
those two numinous substances
are forged into an elixir pellet.
First, you must shatter the web of doubt,
then penetrate the barrier of returning to the root and reviving life.
Let the Red Child ride the dragon,
fetch water from the Palace of *Li*;
let the Metal Lord mount the tiger,
circulate fire to scorch the mountain.
The Metal Lord remains silent,
the Enchanted Maiden gathers her sleeves—
in a single hour, the elixir is wrought.
Swallow it whole,
and you will attain the adamantine indestructibility,
transcending the human realm.

**II**
Dwelling in the Mystery Gate,
without encountering a true master,
you labor in vain.
If you sever learning and non-action,
how can you know opening and closing?
With much learning and wide knowledge,
how can you escape the dust of roots and dust?
Clinging to the natural,
you end in annihilation—
clinging to being or non-being, neither is real.
All is false—
where is the subtlety in those stars?
Seek out a master of the highest order.

**III**
A single word breaks open the primordial cause,
pointing straight to the essence of the elixir head—
*jing*, *qi*, and *shen*.
Ask where the Mysterious Pass lies:
it has no fixed location.
The two numinous substances
reside only in heart and body.
Movement and stillness interdepend,
being and non-being interpenetrate—
the five *qi* return to the origin, and myriad virtues gather.
In the profound and wondrous place,
cluster the One Origin
into a single hour.

**IV**
The Dao speaks of the Five Phases,
Buddhism of the Five Eyes,
Confucianism of the Five Constants.
Moreover, benevolence, righteousness, propriety, wisdom—
trust is their root;
metal, wood, water, fire—
earth abides at the center.
White Tiger, Azure Dragon,
Dark Turtle, Vermilion Bird—
all emerge from the Five Lords of the Celestial Hook.
The celestial number is five;
the human spirit, *hun*, *po*,
and intent belong to the Central Yellow.
Heaven and Earth reveal the two fives in full—
when the three and five unite,
the marvel of returning to the origin is beyond measure.
Fire, two, in the south;
east, three, makes five;
north, the Mysterious True One;
west, four, is its kin.
The five earths of the central palace,
combined into three and five—
three and five merge, yin returns to yang.
The adept of the Mysterious,
with lead, silver, cinnabar, mercury,
refines them into adamantine gold.

**V**
The Dao is fundamentally empty and formless,
the formless gives birth to the One,
the One and Two become Three.
From Three, the myriad things are born—
all things are transformed by emptiness,
form after form is transmitted,
thing after thing interpenetrates.
Each body is fundamentally empty,
each head is originally One—
this is not to be discussed casually by ordinary people.
The wonder of emptiness and formlessness
possesses form, name, and appearance,
encompassed within the empty.
Delve deeply into the secret meaning within emptiness—
to reach the ultimate emptiness,
inquire of Lao Dan.
That empty and quiescent stillness,
the ultimate within the non-existent;
emptiness and formlessness thoroughly realized,
piercing the teachings of Gautama.
Before the Emperor of Images,
beyond the Shore of Thunderous Sound—
who else but the pure, empty, and formless?
All the hosts of the Mysterious,
through emptiness and formlessness, meet the Dao—
bowing in reverence, they pay homage.

**VI**
Who clasps hands?
Who joins palms?
Who raises a fist?
These mere tricks—
people still misunderstand them.
The wondrous principle of non-action—
who truly grasps and upholds it?
For all of you,
I clearly set forth:
Laozi, Gautama, and Confucius are one.
Ponder past and present—
the thousand worthies and ten thousand sages
are all the work of human hands.
Pitiful are later learners, devoid of knowledge—
distinguishing right from wrong,
true from false, has no end.
Moreover, heaven, earth, and humanity
share a single source, divided in response;
Daoists, Confucians, and Buddhists—
one principle, what doubt is there?
Seeing nature and illuminating the heart,
probing the subtle and reaching life’s end—
to be a Buddha or an immortal lies only in this.
After the work is accomplished,
though paths differ and schools diverge,
in the end, they all return to the same.

**VII**
I tell you, learners:
fire has no weight,
timing has no hexagrams or lines.
There is no drawing forth or adding,
no action to be taken—
no form or image,
no need for refinement or firing.
Each is unreal,
all is false—
to labor with intent is but vain toil.
Do you understand?
All sounds and sights
are but confusion and delusion.
Cast aside seeing, hearing, knowing, and awareness—
strike through to the numinous terrace, leaving not a single hair.
No more talk of furnaces and hearths,
no seeking of medicinal substances.
The numinous remains undimmed,
the will and power firm and steadfast.
The spirit-chamber is empty and at ease,
the numinous source clear and still—
within it, naturally, heaven and earth commune.
Those who attain perfection—
if they do not perfect their true nature,
how can they escape the kalpas’ turning?

**VIII**
*Oral Instructions for Jing’an*
The primordial spirit spanning kalpas,
the ancestral *qi* from the beginningless,
the primordial essence of the Great Origin—
these three supreme treasures
share a single root and stem.
If you seek the truth,
do not cling to bodily form.
Calm the breath, settle the spirit,
abide in emptiness, solidify the *qi*—
in purity and non-action, essence naturally congeals.
The elixir head forms,
circulate the fire of yin-yang symbols,
gently harmonizing.
Above all, secure and sustain fullness—
refine lead, mercury,
silver, and cinnabar together.
The Four Images harmonize,
the foundation of life is eternally firm;
the Three Origins converge,
awakened nature is empty and numinous.
Nature and life both perfected,
form and spirit both wondrous—
uniting with the Dao, unchanging.
In carefree wandering,
roam the eight poles at will,
free and unfettered.

**IX**
*For Master Qing of Chungu*
Wisdom severs with firm resolve,
the heart rouses with decisive ardor—
thus the Mysterious Pass is penetrated.

**For Master Qing of Chungu (continued)**
Grasp the blade that slays with ease,
gently reveal the knife that revives—
slowly teach its use.
A single sword cleaves the sky,
ten thousand entanglements swept away,
then trust that Śākyamuni and Laozi are one.
The Mysterious Wind spreads—
behold spring blooming in the frozen valley,
a face-to-face encounter with compassion’s visage.
Let snow blanket a thousand peaks—
that jagged, solitary summit
stands blue as indigo.
What of striking bamboo or plucking flowers?
All become relics.
Raising brows, blinking eyes—
mere carelessness.
Beyond kalpas, the radiance of this moment,
here and now, is grasped.
Tear open the mask of appearances,
then cease inquiry.
What is the ancestral master’s intent?
Palms pressed, bowing in reverence.

**For Zhang Xiwei of Kuocang, styled Jian’an**
Unknowing, unhearing,
soundless, scentless—
this is called *xiwei* (subtle obscurity).
This alone is the wondrous root of perfect truth.
Whoever penetrates it
instantly knows the subtle.
Hearing dharma, hearing sutras,
discoursing on Chan, expounding the Dao—
clinging to forms, mired in texts,
all are false.
Do you yet awaken?
This ordinary daily use
is the entire mystery.
Still, rely on decisive ardor in practice—
gather the Four Images,
the Five Phases,
return them to their source.
Master the marvelous union of the Two Modes,
the convergence of the Three Origins.
One spirit undimmed,
ten thousand transformations return.
Essence and *qi* congeal into spirit,
passions revert to nature.
Forth streams the toad’s light,
illuminating all realms.
In wondrous form and spirit,
beyond the Great Void,
alone stands the towering peak.

**The Winding Path and Side Trails**
Three thousand six hundred gates,
each differing in method.
If you cling to the body,
you remain bound to things.
If you depart from form,
you fall into hollow emptiness.
Without dual practice,
how to proceed?
Abandoning both is illogical.
Cultivators of truth—
if you know not the Mysterious Aperture,
your labor is in vain.
This small marvel is fathomless.
Only by direct seeing
can you reach the root of the lineage.
It cannot be heard,
cannot be grasped.
Gazing, it seems present;
seeking, it vanishes without trace.
Each possesses it from the start,
yet none recognize it.
I reveal this celestial mechanism to you:
the Mysterious Aperture,
the workings of emptiness and creation—
all reside within.

**For Layman Wu on the Alchemical Principle**
In the upward work,
the cauldron stands in the *qian* palace,
the furnace rests in the *kun* position.
This fire-phase is subtle,
requiring no effort—
advancing and retreating,
no need for contrivance.
Yin departs, yang arrives,
clouds drift, rain falls—
the mechanism of mastery lies within.
With the heart settled,
that empty numinosity undimmed,
illuminates the darkest paths.
Once the nature-school awakens to the luminous pearl,
this life-root completes the Supreme Polarity.
Beyond the circling circles,
radiant light emerges.
Within the storing-storing,
alone beholds true suchness.
One *qi* returns to the root,
the six gates interpenetrate.
At this stage, rely wholly on virtue’s support.
Amid the dust of the world,
conceal your edge and sharpness—
a perfected ordinary man.

**For Recluse Zhou, the Leisurely One**
The true cauldron, the true furnace,
neither nonexistent nor existent,
only upright and centered.
Within stillness, apply the work;
in quiescence, revolve the mechanism.
Motionless yet responsive,
subtly interconnected—
the old oyster nurtures its pearl,
the mantis charms its young,
such is the wondrous mechanism,
inexhaustible in marvel.
This alone—
once the knot of doubt is shattered,
suddenly awakens to true emptiness.
Gathering lead without leaving the *kun* palace,
wield the fire-symbol,
stirring the *xun* wind.
From the heart of the northern sea’s waves,
capture the White Tiger.
Within the southern mountain’s fire,
seize the Azure Dragon.
The two substances merge,
the three barriers converge—
refined, the divine elixir fills the cauldron, crimson.
Where to conceal the body?
Harmonizing with light, blending with the world—
this is called *xuantong* (mysterious sameness).

**For Zheng Songxi**
Seeming clumsy, seeming foolish,
seeming indolent, seeming lazy,
seeming dull, seeming witless—
this alone is the daily practice of the profound.
If you truly enact it,
it secretly accords with the divine mechanism.
Scholarly understanding, intellectual knowledge,
the *śrāvaka* and *pratyekabuddha*,
all swell the roots of dust, stuffing the belly—
utterly useless.
Only by dying to the heart, treading the earth,
does life equal heaven’s span.
The golden immortal dwells not in the western sky—
no need to mention the blue-eyed foreigner.
Inquire into the nature-school’s single move:
from emptiness, awaken yourself.
In the life-root’s affairs,
take solidity as the foundation.
Void and solid interpenetrate,
presence and absence merge—
form and spirit unite, ascending to sagehood.
The zenith of Chan is pure.
Behold clouds veiling mountains,
moonlight gilding the pines by the stream.

**For Sun’an on Entering Stillness**
Nine revolutions of effort,
the Three Origins’ creation,
a hundred days to establish the foundation.
Then rouse the spirit,
hold fast to resolve,
overturn delusion,
sever doubt.
Raise the brows,
open the heart—
every thing, every head,
swept away with a single stroke.
In the act of practice,
the Dipper’s handle is dragged sideways,
the celestial sphere revolves in reverse.
In the midst of action, grasp non-action—
that which is not-none,
within it, the most marvelous.
At the threshold of the indistinct,
the verge of the obscure—
to guard it is delusion,
to abandon it is error.
Neither guard nor forget,
neither restrain nor indulge—
examine this *storing-storing-storing*—
who is it?
Just so—
await the completion of the six yang phases,
then embrace the toad’s child.

**For Attendant Wang**
The sea of wisdom, deep and clear,
the mountain of virtue, towering and steep—
the master is no ordinary man.

Moreover, to grind down sharpness and resolve entanglements, to dismiss cunning and set aside cleverness—
overturning self and other, yet leaving no trace of mechanism or restraint.
Resolve stands in emptiness, the mind abides in primordial chaos,
probing the hidden intent before the image of the Lord.
In the depths of the profound—
the old master’s original surname,
one thread through the three.
Once he joined the loftiest adepts in arcane discourse,
thus in silence, in darkness, he merged with Lao Dan.
How much more in the numinous realm of emptiness and leisure,
the zenith of Chan, serene and still—
forgetting knowledge, forgetting perception,
no north, no south.
Gathering in body and mind,
fusing with the workings of creation,
all within is overturned to form a sanctuary.
When the divine elixir is complete,
behold its perfect roundness,
illuminating the Song Hermitage.

**Exhortation to Zhong’an on the Wondrous Use of Holding the Center**
The center is the Confucian lineage,
the center is the Daoist root,
the center is the Chan mechanism.
Of the three teachings’ family ways,
the center is the swiftest path;
of the five constants and hundred practices,
the center establishes the foundation.
In movement and stillness, attain the center,
hold fast to the center without wavering—
then peer into the subtleties within the center.
Within its essence lies the delight,
revealed in words—
beware of doubt.
Do you yet know the workings of this center?
It lies neither in the midst nor the four directions.
In daily life’s plainness,
through the center it operates;
in rising, dwelling, eating, and drinking,
all is enacted within the center.
Penetrate this center,
and you grasp the center’s body—
the character "center" originally admits no opposition.
When the center is fully realized,
split it open with the center—
only then are you a true man.

**For Abbot Yuan of the Round Hermitage**
The human heart is perilous,
the heart of Dao is subtle,
within the center lies the mechanism of transformation.
Where is its wondrousness?
It arises from no contrivance,
luminous and unobscured,
the radiance of wisdom’s moon.
Whether called *qi* or spirit,
whether refined or unified,
like jade without flaw, heaven and earth return to it.
In the realm of the profound,
take the single stroke within Kan,
and move it into Li of the South.
The red dragon coils around the black turtle,
in the sixth month, frost bears strange fruit.
That white-haired old man
comes to wed the plain maiden;
when the fetal immortal’s dance concludes,
they enter the yellow curtain together.
Clouds bring rain, winds carry harmony,
yin and yang flow in accord—
a year’s effort nurtures the child.
Constantly nurture it,
awaiting the Jade Emperor’s decree,
then ascend on clouds to return.

**Exhortation to All Disciples**
The Dao resides in ordinary people,
in the midst of daily use—
yet people remain unaware.
Alas, amidst the tangled web of perceptions,
the surging red dust,
the spirit’s source is unsettled,
the moon of the heart lacks radiance.
The mountain of self and other looms high,
the sea of right and wrong stretches wide—
overturn all, and you approach the subtle.
All you noble ones,
hear the parable of the Clear Hermitage—
beware of doubt.
First take purity as the foundation,
use stillness and stability
as the hermitage’s self-sustaining abode.
Let the center be the gate,
rectitude the forest and couch,
sincerity the path,
reverence the fence.
Be humble and yielding with others,
modest and respectful in dealings—
in eating, dwelling, rising, and resting, do not transgress.
Practice this constantly,
and if your effort never slackens,
you will enter non-action directly.

**To the Tune *Man Jiang Hong*: For Xu’an**
In daily practice,
only one flavor—
embrace emptiness, hold to simplicity.
When diverse paths converge as one,
a hundred thoughts unite in singularity.
In the Purple Pole Palace, the primal *qi* breathes;
within the suspended crucible, the three flowers gather.
Ask how to tend the furnace, establish the crucible—
cast with the metal of Qian.
Bind the golden crow,
seize the jade hare,
capture them,
seal them in the earthen cauldron.
In the firing’s ebb and flow,
take greater care in guarding.
When the jade treasure is perfectly formed, it shines in entry and exit;
the Dharma-body’s form leaves no trace of coming or going.
Then conceal yourself,
ascend directly to the Great Clarity Palace—
the spirit abides eternally.

**In Praise of Shui’an, Steward Yin**
Who is the hermitage’s child?
Who stands within,
upholding the hermitage?
Seeing hunger come, he eats—
who knows the sweet and bitter?
The notes of horn and zither—who discerns them?
The hues of blue, yellow, black, and white—who can perceive them?
In the ordinary exchanges of daily life,
who makes the distinctions?
Who walks?
Who lifts?
Who is silent?
Who speaks?
Penetrate these,
and you know host and guest.
The outer form—who fashions it?
The inner gate—who comes and goes?
In non-action’s end,
who ultimately dwells in the hermitage,
the Scarlet Mound Palace?

**Instructions for Jue’an**
The Dao is fundamentally natural—
but to act is error at every turn.
If you merely discourse on emptiness,
how can you grasp it?
To forget both being and non-being never concludes;
to employ both sides is to be ensnared.
Nothing compares to silently guarding the center—
the spirit at ease, joyful.
Past affairs—
forget them.
Future matters—
do not ponder.
In the present’s work,
do not cling.
The six desires do not arise, the three poisons are extinguished;
when the single yang returns, the host of yin is stripped away.
Awaken to true emptiness,
embrace the root and return to original emptiness—
this is true awakening.

**For Magistrate Ding: The Three Teachings Share One Principle**
The three teachings’ true transmission—
this path,
originally so direct.
Ask of Laozi’s mechanism—
ultimate emptiness, utmost stillness.
The Buddha’s nature is awakened within emptiness;
Confucius’ principle enters through sincerity.
From the beginning, though the teachings branched into three,
their source is one.
The Dao’s mysterious gate
constantly responds to things.
The *Yi*’s subtleties
must be silently grasped.
The Chan school’s profound essence—
true emptiness, utmost quiescence.
Moment by moment, uphold it without interruption;
lifetimes of use know no end.
Then return to the root,
restore life to the body of original emptiness—
concealed in utmost secrecy.

**For Li the Sleeping Daoist Judge**
A fine sleeping family tradition—
another kind of
sleeping samadhi.
As long as the heart is sincere in sleep,
the mind is clarified within sleep.
Once the method of sleep is mastered,
within sleep you harmonize spirit and *qi*.
This sleeping practice—
its subtleties in peaceful Chan—
few understand.
Though the body sleeps,
the nature is not obscured;
though the eyes droop,
the inner vision is not closed.
In deep sleep,
steady and secure—
a pillow of cool breeze chills the bones,
dreaming beyond the world in carefree play.
Upon waking,
the body rests in the Palace of Broad Cold,
embracing the toad in slumber.

**In Praise of Layman Fu of the Round Hermitage**
This circle,
since time immemorial,
has borne no form.
Moreover, upright and proper,
poised and balanced—
entering the finest dust, it leaves no shadow;
encompassing the cosmos, it finds no place to rest.

Yet it traverses heaven and earth, unbound in all directions,
no barriers obstruct.
Rootless origin, formless state—
glittering bright, radiant and round.
This alone is the original visage.
Released, it soars straight beyond the formless realms;
recalled, it hides within the treasury of light.
Wait until the crown bursts open to reveal perfect penetration—
the golden countenance.

**In Praise of Prefect Zhang of Zhi Hermitage**
Only upright, only centered—
this is the secret formula for cultivating immortality.
Should there be the slightest bias,
movement breeds distinction.
Try to maintain steadfastness amid motion,
and naturally within stillness the mechanism becomes thorough.
Comprehending the Three Origins and Five *qi* entering the Yellow Court,
golden flowers bloom.

The firing process has its seasons:
the ocean tide rises, the moon in the sky.
That which ascends and descends,
waxes and wanes.
Ten months of unbroken effort,
and the wondrous one transcends birth and death.
If you ask me of the matter beyond—
no words suffice.

**In Praise of Mi Hermitage’s Exposition of the Three Teachings**
There are three teachings,
yet at their ultimate point, they are originally one.
This single-character Dharma-gate
is fathomless in depth.
Laozi’s Valley Spirit is ever undying,
Confucius’ *Xin Yi* initially without design.
Ask of Śākyamuni’s mind beyond teaching—Nirvāṇa—
profound, profound, profound.

To learn the immortal’s way, stabilize the breath.
To learn the sage’s way, forget knowledge and perception.
As for the Buddha’s mechanism of attainment,
it relies solely on the power of wisdom.
Daoist, Buddhist, and Confucian streams—all are penetrated,
the work of perfect clarity and luminous awareness complete.
Behold the crown breaking through to see true suchness—
radiance blazing.

**In Praise of Zong the Daoist of Wei Hermitage**
The work of observing return
requires silent, steadfast preservation.
In the midst of extreme stillness, a single movement—
then the mysterious and the female are penetrated.
Within the indistinct and vague, emotion merges with nature;
in the valley of emptiness, the marvelous finds its match.
Now I take the supreme mechanism of the ancestral masters
and dissect it for you.

That which speaks
does not depend on the mouth.
That which grasps things
does not depend on the hand.

The legless child
can somersault.
Grasp but a sliver of the marvelous,
and naturally you’ll penetrate "being within non-being."
Ask what the true meaning of "coming from the West" is—
it’s twisting the nose into shackles.

**In Praise of Mi’an**
A single grain of golden elixir,
its origin—who knows the kalpas?
If you don’t recognize the root-source,
how can you harmonize it?
Moreover, it’s what you’ve always inherently possessed—
why cling to forms and contrive needlessly?
I clearly reveal it to you, seekers of immortality—
the celestial mechanism laid bare.

Soft as silk,
hard as iron.
Sharp as gold,
round as the moon.
Yet neither square nor round,
without flaw or lack.
Release it, and it opens the aperture of heaven and earth;
withdraw it, and it hides in the cave of emptiness.
Ask what it is when neither released nor withdrawn—
hard to describe.

**In Praise of Yi’an**
The true mechanism of the Three and Five,
in application—everywhere it is so.
Moreover, in daily use, ordinary and constant,
it stands majestic and silent.
Within being and non-being, forget dualistic views,
and you’ll penetrate the samadhi of formlessness.
Yet how can it be "less" or "more"?
It’s hindered by clinging to distinctions.

The lead of the watery realm—
just this one flavor.
This alone is
the primordial qi.
When the toad and crow unite as jade,
body and mind merge in harmony.
From the West’s four, return to the North’s completion;
from the East’s three, join the South’s two.
Gather the five kinds into the crucible—
the elixir is complete.

**In Praise of Layman Sun**
This speck of numinous emptiness,
from ancient times—
without flaw or lack.
Ever radiant, ever round,
ever limpid, ever clear.
It illuminates the primordial chaos of former affairs,
distinguishes the idle caves amid the moon’s hollows.
Within the hermitage, nurture a white toad—
bright as snow.

That which is,
cannot be spoken.
Sharp as gold,
round as the moon.

The transformations give rise to life, life to transformations—
ceaseless, without rest.
When the misty waters swirl, Heaven’s Essence descends;
where the earthly thunder stirs, dark frost congeals.
Mounting the azure phoenix,
one ascends straight to the Palace of Broad Cold—
transcending birth and extinction.

**In Praise of the Silent Hermitage**
Silence is speech—
yet in this speaking, silence originally abides.
This silent speech alone
is the secret formula of the golden elixir.
Silent recognition, subtle communion—this is the great essential;
the paths of Hearers and Pratyeka-Buddhas are but empty constructs.
Within speech, discern the root of silence—
beyond birth and extinction.

Those who speak
are not bound to the tongue.
What is silent
differs not from speech.
Yet this silence—
how could it compare to speech’s intimacy?
If one finds the flavor in wordlessness,
then in non-silence, all is thoroughly penetrated.
When silence and speech are both overturned,
the celestial mechanism is revealed.

**In Praise of Hermit Ge of the Reverent Hermitage**
The Dao is fundamentally wordless,
yet the learner must subtly commune, silently recognize.
When all thoughts are relinquished,
the numinous emptiness shines pure and still.
In movement, harmonize fire within water;
in stillness, fathom the perfection of Pāramitā.
Ask: where lies the mysterious pass, the single aperture?
Seek it in the center.

It is not mind,
nor thing.
Not immortal,
nor Buddha.
Only this truth—
few indeed know it.
The deluded toil in vain to the end;
awakening comes without the least effort.
Behold: from nothingness, being arises—
the spiritual embryo is born, the yang spirit emerges.

**A Prophecy for Disciples**
The mysterious pass of my Dao
admits no outsider to enter.

When seekers come to inquire, guard against their thievery.
Brandish fiercely the blade that slays the living—
yet with a healer’s touch, lightly reveal the art.
Lift high the single thread, flaunt your spiritual prowess—
who could withstand it?

If one is a true vessel of wisdom,
they will rise to the challenge, their heart unwavering.
Rely on resolute courage and boldness:
meet the Buddha, slay the Buddha.
Each step outshines the ten sages;
each word devours the three realms.
Upheave heaven and earth, overturn the cosmos—
truly extraordinary!

**Instructions to Disciples on Returning with the Elixir**
Upon gathering the medicine, this crucible—
forged of unyielding metal—
holds no principle but that which the master commands.
First sweep clean the roots of perception,
abandon all former attachments.
Ask: how to proceed with the firing process?
Rely on prajñā.

The chariot of the five thunders,
the Green Dragon’s grasp.
The talisman for burning mountains,
engraved upon the heart.
Further, purify thoughts, wash the mind,
bathe in the numinous spring.
When the ninefold work is complete and the Dao of the elixir fulfilled,
the single spirit returns to emptiness.
That naked, unadorned Dharmarāja-body—
nothing to grasp.

**To the Tune of "Court Full of Fragrance" – For Prefect Jiao**
In the solitude of mountain dwelling,
amid the clamor of market seclusion—
each and all are the mysterious pass.
Wise and enlightened scholars,
must seek it within stillness.

I wield the healer’s art—
yet it is the blade that slays, slowly taught for you to see.
Should you awaken now, grasp this truth at once,
and liberation will not be difficult.
A single word—
plainly spoken, breaking open the way:
at the outset, begin with the threefold three.
From the Mysterious Palace, kindle the fire,
and circulate it into Kun Mountain.
Hold fast—then clouds mass at the valley’s mouth;
release it—then the moon sinks into the cold pool.
When the work is complete and the cycle fulfilled,
the great toad takes form,
and your name is inscribed among the immortals’ ranks.

**Further – For Master Ding’an, Who Received the Record**
To study Buddha, to study immortality,
to investigate Chan, to fathom principle—
all remain within the Mysterious Female’s gate.
Pitiful are those lost in delusion,
ever deceiving themselves with empty forms.
They pluck leaves and chase branches in vain,
wearing through mat after mat in futile sitting.
How lamentable—
seeking without while the truth lies within,
mocking old Gautama.

A touch of true creation:
if you could but witness it directly,
your gall would chill, your heart grow cold.
Noble scholar of Ding’an,
you must seek it within stillness.
See through the face you were born with,
and overturn all past learning and understanding.
True emptiness pierces through,
the skull shatters,
and the true master departs the hermitage.

**To the Tune of "Prelude to Water Melody" – For Inspector Wang of He’an**
The earthen crucible must be upright,
its steadiness questioned of the Yellow Elder.
Flow from wu to ji,
awaiting the mountain’s hidden spring to rise.
Gather the medicine—beware haste;
temper the firing—avoid excess.
The virtue lies in attaining the center.
Holding to the center is never easy,
yet heaven’s principle responds and opens.

That subtle, wondrous point—
truly hard to fathom.
Since the day I grasped it,
there has been no day in this hermitage without spring’s breeze.

Then marry the Western Maiden to the Southern Child of Ling,
their union forever harmonious and shared.
By the tenth month, the sacred embryo is complete,
shedding its shell to gleam in the void.

**To Master Zhou Qiuchan**
Lead and mercury leave no trace,
the crucible and furnace but borrowed names.
At first, movement and stillness delude men,
unawares, they fall into the realm of sound and form.
This wondrous principle of prior heaven,
in daily life—dressing and eating—
stands before you, utterly clear.
In responding to things as they arise,
stillness moves and awakens.
Not the mind, not the Buddha,
nor is it gold.
Sharpen your vision,
lest you mistake the fixed pole star.
Scattered, the clouds of delusion dissolve;
limpid, the zenith of meditation alone emerges—
this is the original truth.
When the wind stills, the waves subside;
the moon fills, and the water’s light turns clear.

**To Master Baochanzi**
To learn the Buddha or the immortal’s way,
profound mystery lies in sincerity.
True lead, true mercury—
nothing but nature and emotion.
When emotion returns to nature,
lead flows to meet mercury,
and the two unite of themselves.
In daily use, no gap remains;
the great elixir forms naturally.
Know when to draw back, when to advance,
how to maintain fullness.
The earthen crucible, the heavenly furnace,
yin talismans and yang fire—temper them slowly.
Once the mysterious pass is pierced,
the eight petals of the crown shatter,
and the radiant toad bursts forth.
With merit and practice both perfected,
laughing, you may pay homage to the Three Pure Ones.

---

**To Layman Liu**
In the world yet not of it,
dust does not cling to dust.
Abiding in centeredness,
what matter if in market or mountain forest?
Walk without bias or deviation,
in daily life, without contention or attachment—
this alone is the perfect truth.
Let not the square inch of the heart grow dim,
and you are a master of the highest vehicle.
Gather primordial essence,
refine primordial qi,
restore primordial spirit.
When the three primordials unite,
the great elixir naturally congeals within the crucible.
Then stir the mysterious wind,
dispel the wandering clouds beyond heaven,
and the moon of wisdom shines bright.
Knock at the gate of the first principle,
and the river’s peaks stand green.

---

**To Zhang Meng’an**
Thunder lies dormant in the earth,
a hidden spring gushes beneath the mountain.
Grasp these two principles,
and creation naturally aligns with the mysterious.
Guard stillness in perfect emptiness,
and in the midst of nothingness, wondrous being appears—
the nine orifices open as one.
Proceed directly to claim it—
this is the true master.
Do not cling to non-being,
do not cling to being,
do not cling to emptiness.
Shatter the knot of doubt,
and suddenly you stand atop the wondrous peak.
Sweep away the clutter of external realms,
gather that which is numinous and luminous,
and creation knows no bounds.
What, in the end, is to be said?
The sun rises east of the ridge.

---

**To Master Shian**
The Dao is the body of the Dharma,
the Dharma is the surplus of the Dao.
When Dao and Dharma are both complete,
all things—whether grasped or inverted—are at your command.
This very primordial spirit and primordial qi
are the celestial soldiers and generals;
beyond them, there is nothing.
I tell you, Master Dongchan:
within stillness, do the work.

Guard it as the embryo,
use it as the aperture,
employ it as the talisman.
Once this principle is clear,
why trouble with ink and cinnabar?
If essence is concentrated and qi firm,
you may command thunder and dispatch lightning,
and all demons and monsters will be subdued.
When merit is fulfilled and practice complete,
laughing, you may pay homage to the immortal capital.

**Instructions to the Assembly: Distinguishing This from That**
The three teachings—Daoist, Buddhist, Confucian—
differ in name but not in principle.
Whether meditating or exhausting reason,
only seek to embrace the root and return to the origin.
Grasp the workings of the one center,
and the three primordials converge like spokes,
all chronic ailments vanish.
When the house is firm,
then you may erect the elixir furnace.

Refine the returning elixir,
complete the Great Ultimate,
gather the mysterious pearl.
The subtle mechanism—
draw forth the yang within kan to fill the li.
If you neither crave nor cling,
directly transcend sound and form,
and spirit and qi wholly return to emptiness.
All appearances are comprehended,
and the innocent child emerges from the divine hut.
