chunks.original_text: 便把西方少女，嫁与南陵赤子，相见永和同。 十月圣胎备，脱蜕烁虚空。 又　赠秋蟾周先生 铅汞了无质，炉鼎假安名。 始因动静迷人，不觉堕声闻。 这个先天妙理，日用着衣吃饭，相对甚分明。 接物应机处，不动感而灵。 不是心，不是佛，匪为金。 明加眼力，莫教错认定盘星。 片片迷云涣散，湛湛禅天独露，个是本来真。 风定浪头息，月满水光清。 又　赠宝蟾子 学佛学仙要，玄妙在中诚。 真铅真汞，无非只是性和情。 但得情来归性，便见铅来投汞，二物自交并。 日用了无间，大药自然成。 识抽添，明进退，要持盈。 坤炉乾鼎，阴符阳火慢调停。 一窍玄关透了，八片顶门裂破，迸出宝蟾明。 功行两圆备，谈笑谒三清。 又　赠刘居士 在俗心不俗，尘裹不沾尘。 处身中正，何妨闹市与山林。 践履不偏不易，日用无争无执，只此是全真。 方寸莫教昧，便是上乘人。 采元精，炼元气，复元神。 三元合一，自然鼎内大丹凝。 更把玄风鼓动，天外迷云消散，慧月朗然明。 叩我第一义，江上数峰青。 又　赠张蒙庵 雷在地中复，山下出泉蒙。 明斯二理，自然造化合玄同。 密密至虚守静，便见无中妙有，九窍一齐通。 直下承当去，个是主人公。 莫着无，莫着有，莫着空。 疑团打彻，只今突出妙高峰。 拨置纷纷外境，收拾灵灵底个，生化了无穷。 毕竟作么道，日向岭东红。 又　赠实庵 道乃法之体，法乃道之余。 双全道法，横拈倒用总由渠。 只这元神元气，便是天兵将吏，除此外都无。 说与洞蟾子，定裹做工夫。 守为胎，用为窍，假为符。 既明此理，何须苦泥墨和朱。 若使精凝气固，便可驱雷役电，妖怪悉皆诛。 行满功成日，谈笑谒仙都。 又　示众刍分彼此 道释儒三教，名殊理不殊。 参禅穷理，只要抱本还元初。 解得一中造化，便使三元辐辏，宿疾普消除。 屋舍既坚固，始可立丹炉。 炼还丹，全太极，采玄珠。 的端消息，采将坎有补离无。 若也不贪不爱，直下离声离色，神气总归虚。 了达一切相，赤子出神庐。 又  赠白兰谷 三元秘秋水，微密实难量。 未分清浊，天地人物一包藏。 一乃太玄真水，二气由兹运化，三极理全彰。 上下降升妙，根本在中黄。 兔怀胎，牛喘月，蚌含光。 人明此理，倒提斗柄库银演。 绝断曹溪一派，掀倒蓬莱三岛，无处不仙乡。 谁为白兰谷，安寝感羲皇。 又　言道 三元秘秋水，未悟谩猜量。 诚能参透，洗心涤虑密归藏。 意与身心不动，精与气神交合，天理自然彰。 三善备於我，翻笑炼玄黄。 性圆融，心豁达，德辉光。 牛郎织女，一时会合到天潢。 勘破乘槎伎俩，密契浴沂消息，游泳有无乡。 日用别无事，读易对三皇。 又　言性 三元秘秋水，都不属思量。 收来毫末，放开大地不能藏。 过去未来见在，只是星儿消息，体物显然彰。 本自无形象，随处见青黄。 性源清，心地静，发天光。 木人半夜，倒骑铁马过银潢。 正是露寒烟冷，那更风清月白，乘兴水云乡。 识破梦中梦，稽首礼虚皇。 百字令 赠真蟾子叶大师 玄关欲透，做工夫、妙在一阳来复。 天癸才生忙下手，采处切须虔笃。 绝虑忘机，清心释累，认取虚无谷。 铅银砂汞，一时辰内攒簇。 霎时天地相交，甲庚无间，龙虎齐降伏。 取坎填离，乾体就、阳火阴符行足。
chunks.translated_text:
Then marry the Western Maiden to the Southern Child of Ling,
their union forever harmonious and shared.
By the tenth month, the sacred embryo is complete,
shedding its shell to gleam in the void.

---

**To Master Zhou Qiuchan**
Lead and mercury leave no trace,
the crucible and furnace but borrowed names.
At first, movement and stillness delude men,
unawares, they fall into the realm of sound and form.
This wondrous principle of prior heaven,
in daily life—dressing and eating—
stands before you, utterly clear.
In responding to things as they arise,
stillness moves and awakens.
Not the mind, not the Buddha,
nor is it gold.
Sharpen your vision,
lest you mistake the fixed pole star.
Scattered, the clouds of delusion dissolve;
limpid, the zenith of meditation alone emerges—
this is the original truth.
When the wind stills, the waves subside;
the moon fills, and the water’s light turns clear.

---

**To Master Baochanzi**
To learn the Buddha or the immortal’s way,
profound mystery lies in sincerity.
True lead, true mercury—
nothing but nature and emotion.
When emotion returns to nature,
lead flows to meet mercury,
and the two unite of themselves.
In daily use, no gap remains;
the great elixir forms naturally.
Know when to draw back, when to advance,
how to maintain fullness.
The earthen crucible, the heavenly furnace,
yin talismans and yang fire—temper them slowly.
Once the mysterious pass is pierced,
the eight petals of the crown shatter,
and the radiant toad bursts forth.
With merit and practice both perfected,
laughing, you may pay homage to the Three Pure Ones.

---

**To Layman Liu**
In the world yet not of it,
dust does not cling to dust.
Abiding in centeredness,
what matter if in market or mountain forest?
Walk without bias or deviation,
in daily life, without contention or attachment—
this alone is the perfect truth.
Let not the square inch of the heart grow dim,
and you are a master of the highest vehicle.
Gather primordial essence,
refine primordial qi,
restore primordial spirit.
When the three primordials unite,
the great elixir naturally congeals within the crucible.
Then stir the mysterious wind,
dispel the wandering clouds beyond heaven,
and the moon of wisdom shines bright.
Knock at the gate of the first principle,
and the river’s peaks stand green.

---

**To Zhang Meng’an**
Thunder lies dormant in the earth,
a hidden spring gushes beneath the mountain.
Grasp these two principles,
and creation naturally aligns with the mysterious.
Guard stillness in perfect emptiness,
and in the midst of nothingness, wondrous being appears—
the nine orifices open as one.
Proceed directly to claim it—
this is the true master.
Do not cling to non-being,
do not cling to being,
do not cling to emptiness.
Shatter the knot of doubt,
and suddenly you stand atop the wondrous peak.
Sweep away the clutter of external realms,
gather that which is numinous and luminous,
and creation knows no bounds.
What, in the end, is to be said?
The sun rises east of the ridge.

---

**To Master Shian**
The Dao is the body of the Dharma,
the Dharma is the surplus of the Dao.
When Dao and Dharma are both complete,
all things—whether grasped or inverted—are at your command.
This very primordial spirit and primordial qi
are the celestial soldiers and generals;
beyond them, there is nothing.
I tell you, Master Dongchan:
within stillness, do the work.

Guard it as the embryo,
use it as the aperture,
employ it as the talisman.
Once this principle is clear,
why trouble with ink and cinnabar?
If essence is concentrated and qi firm,
you may command thunder and dispatch lightning,
and all demons and monsters will be subdued.
When merit is fulfilled and practice complete,
laughing, you may pay homage to the immortal capital.

---

**Instructions to the Assembly: Distinguishing This from That**
The three teachings—Daoist, Buddhist, Confucian—
differ in name but not in principle.
Whether meditating or exhausting reason,
only seek to embrace the root and return to the origin.
Grasp the workings of the one center,
and the three primordials converge like spokes,
all chronic ailments vanish.
When the house is firm,
then you may erect the elixir furnace.

Refine the returning elixir,
complete the Great Ultimate,
gather the mysterious pearl.
The subtle mechanism—
draw forth the yang within kan to fill the li.
If you neither crave nor cling,
directly transcend sound and form,
and spirit and qi wholly return to emptiness.
All appearances are comprehended,
and the innocent child emerges from the divine hut.

---

**To Bai Langu**
The three primordials hide in autumn waters,
subtle and profound, beyond measure.
Before clear and turbid divided,
heaven, earth, and humanity were one.
This is the true water of the Great Mystery;
from it, the two qi transform and operate,
and the principles of the three ultimates are fully revealed.
The marvel of ascent and descent,
the root lies in the central yellow.
The rabbit bears the embryo,
the ox pants at the moon,
the clam holds the light.
When one understands this principle,
the Dipper’s handle is upturned, and the treasury’s silver unfolds.
Sever the lineage of Caoxi,
overturn the three isles of Penglai—
nowhere is not a land of immortals.
Who is this Bai Langu?
At ease, he moves the Fuxi’s heart.

---

**On the Dao**
The three primordials hide in autumn waters,
yet without awakening, one vainly speculates.
If you can truly penetrate it,
wash the heart and cleanse the thoughts, returning to hidden depths.
Let intention, body, and heart remain unmoved;
essence, qi, and spirit merge,
and heaven’s principle naturally manifests.
The three virtues are complete within me—
I laugh at those who refine the mysterious and yellow.

Nature is all-embracing,
the heart open and vast,
virtue radiant.
The Cowherd and Weaver Girl,
at once unite in the celestial river.
See through the tricks of riding the raft,
secretly align with the message of bathing in the Yi—
swim in the realm of being and non-being.
In daily life, there is nothing else;
reading the *Yi* before the Three Sovereigns.

---

**On Nature**
The three primordials hide in autumn waters,
yet none belong to thought.
Gather them to the finest point,
release them, and even the earth cannot contain them.
Past, future, present—
only the stars’ subtle message,
manifesting in things, is clearly revealed.
Originally without form,
it appears everywhere as blue and yellow.

The source of nature is pure,
the ground of the heart still,
emitting celestial light.
The wooden man at midnight,
riding an iron horse across the silver river.
Just as dew chills and mist cools,
with wind clear and moon bright,
ride the interest to the land of water and clouds.
See through the dream within the dream,
and bow to the August Void.

---

**To the Tune of "Hundred-Character Command": For Master Zhenchanzi Ye**
To pierce the mysterious pass,
in your practice, await the return of the first yang.
When heavenly water begins to flow, act swiftly—
in gathering, be reverent and sincere.
Cut off thoughts, forget schemes,
purify the heart, release burdens,
and recognize the valley of emptiness.
Lead, silver, cinnabar, mercury—
in a single moment, they gather.

In an instant, heaven and earth unite,
the stems of jiǎ and gēng merge without gap,
dragon and tiger both submit.
Draw forth the kan to fill the li,
complete the body of qián—
yang fire and yin talismans, their work fulfilled.

chunks.original_text: 至宝凝坚，真蟾形兆，宜把灵泉沃。 德圆功备，大师名注仙箓。 又　指中庵性命次序 玄关一窍，理幽深、至妙了无言说。 阴极阳生初动处，便是采铅时节。 地下雷轰，山头水降，满地红尘雪。 行功之际，马猿休纵颠劣。 霎时虎啸龙吟，夫惧妇合，鼎内丹头结。 身外有身犹未了，圆顿始能通彻。 郁郁黄花，青青翠竹，此理应难泄。 为君举似，水中捞取明月。 又　赠陈制干 修真慕道，乐清虚、任意陶陶兀兀。 富贵荣华都不恋，甘分清贫彻骨。 名利俱损，是非不辨，且把身埋没。 真闲真静，谁知如是消息。 为言向上机缄，玄珠罔象，火候无时刻。 一窍玄关通得透，顿悟非心非佛。 情念双忘，有无交入，胎备元神出。 眼睛开放，光明周遍无极。 又　赠胡秀才 亘初一点，莹如如、无相无形无质。 不荡不摇常正定，直是断踪绝迹。 变化无方，显微无间，妙理应难测。 为伊言破，屏除缘虑尘识。 放教方寸虚澄，裹头宁贴，方见真端的。 三五混融心月皎，照破本元来历。 烁烁圆明，如如不动，运化无休息。 静中拈出，蟾光烁破无极。 又　指老蟾张大夫下手 金丹大要，不难知、妙在阳时下手。 日用平常须谨独，莫纵虎龙奔走。 心要安闲，身须正定，意在常存守。 始终不怠，自然通透玄牡。 其间些子淆讹，为公直指，地下听雷吼。 立鼎安炉非小可，运用斡旋凭斗。 性本圆明，命基牢固，勘破无中有。 老蟾成象，直同天地齐寿。 又  赠通庵 太初一点，本灵明、元自至纯无杂。 执着些儿千里远，悟得只消时霎。 方寸中虚，纤尘不立，何用调庚甲。 承当得去，目前方信无法。 个中显诀难传，无名可唤，贵在心通达。 信手拈来君荐取，无罅岂容针札。 人我山头，是非海裹，更要知生杀。 养其无象，忘形灵地开发。 又　示众破惑 成仙捷径，在玄关、一窍四通八达。 说与学人先立志，悟后只消时霎。 可笑迷徒，不求师指，执着傍门法。 般精般气，到头都是兜搭。 争知大道堂堂，坦平蓦直，也要师开发。 会得善行无辙迹，玄牝自然开阖。 一念无生，谷神不死，九转工周匝。 脱胎归去，大罗天上行踏。 西江月　赠潘道人 真土真铅真汞，元神元气元精。 三元合一药方成，个是全真上品。 动静虚灵不昧，成全实相圆明。 形神俱妙乐无生，直谒虚皇绝境。 又　赠善友 至道本无言说，全凭立志刚坚。 心常不昧究根源，一月千潭普现。 会取击风捕影，便知火裹栽莲。 任他海水变桑田，只这本来无变。 又　赠周守正 识破无人无我，何须求佛求仙。 随时随处总安禅，一切幻尘不染。 选甚山居野处，何妨闹市门前。 执中守正固三田，久久神珠出现。 炼丹砂　咏玄牝示众 玄牝少人通，说与诸公。 休言南北与西东。 不在四维并上下，不在当中。 阖辟妙无穷，天地根宗。 生生化化运神功。 动静机缄应不息，广纳包容。 又　示众 至道本无传，只要心坚。 始终立志莫教偏。 九载三年常一定，便是神仙。 真息自绵绵，灵地平平。 饥来吃饭困来眠。 夏月单衣冬盖被，玄外无玄。 隐语 教外名言
chunks.translated_text:
The supreme treasure congeals and hardens,
the true toad’s form emerges—
it is fitting to bathe it with the numinous spring.
Virtue perfected, merit complete,
the master’s name is inscribed in the immortal register.

---

**On the Sequence of Nature and Life at Zhong’an Hermitage**
The mysterious pass is but one aperture,
its principle profound, its subtlety beyond words.
At the moment when yin reaches its extreme and yang begins to stir,
there lies the season for gathering lead.
Thunder rumbles beneath the earth,
water descends from mountain peaks,
and the red dust of the world is blanketed in snow.
In the midst of practice,
restrain the horse and ape—let them not run wild.

In an instant, the tiger roars and the dragon sings,
husband and wife unite,
and within the crucible, the elixir’s head takes form.
Yet to have a body beyond the body is still not the ultimate—
only through sudden perfection can one attain thorough comprehension.
Lush yellow blossoms,
verdant green bamboo—
this principle is not easily divulged.
For you, I raise it as an example:
scooping the bright moon from the water.

---

**To Chen Zhigan**
In cultivating the Dao and longing for truth,
delight in clarity and emptiness,
freely and blissfully abiding in stillness.
Wealth, honor, and glory—none are clung to,
content with utter poverty to the bone.
Name and profit both relinquished,
right and wrong unrecognized,
one buries the self away.
Truly at leisure, truly still—
who knows the message in this?

I speak of the mechanism beyond all mechanisms,
the formless pearl of mystery,
the fire’s timing without fixed moment.
Once the aperture of the mysterious pass is fully penetrated,
sudden awakening is neither mind nor Buddha.
Dualities of thought forgotten,
being and non-being intermingle,
and the embryo prepares for the primordial spirit to emerge.
The eyes open wide,
radiance pervades boundlessly.

---

**To Scholar Hu**
From the beginning, a single point,
luminous and thus—
without form, without shape, without substance.
Unmoving, unshaken, ever in perfect stillness,
truly cutting off all traces.
Transforming without limit,
manifesting and subtle without gap,
its wondrous principle defies conjecture.
For you, I reveal it:
banish all karmic thoughts and worldly knowledge.

Let the square inch of the heart be emptied and stilled,
the head wrapped and settled,
only then will the true essence be seen.
The three and five merge, the heart-moon gleams,
illuminating the origin and history of the original source.
Flickering, round, and bright,
thus and unmoving,
its transformations ceaseless.
In stillness, it is grasped—
the toad’s light blazes beyond all bounds.

---

**Instructing Minister Zhang, the Old Toad, on Where to Begin**
The great essentials of the golden elixir
are not hard to know—
the subtlety lies in acting when yang arises.
In daily life, be ever vigilant in solitude,
lest the tiger and dragon flee.
The heart must be at ease,
the body firmly settled,
the intent constantly preserved.
Unwavering from start to finish,
naturally the mysterious gate will open.

Amid minor confusions,
I point directly for you:
listen to the thunder’s roar beneath the earth.
Erecting the crucible and installing the furnace is no small matter—
their operation and rotation depend on the Dipper.
Nature is originally round and bright,
life’s foundation firm,
having seen through the "nothing" that contains "something."
The old toad takes form,
its lifespan equal to heaven and earth.

---

**To Tong’an**
In the great beginning, a single point—
fundamentally numinous and bright,
inherently pure and without admixture.
Clinging to even the slightest bit leads one a thousand miles astray,
yet awakening takes but an instant.
The heart’s square inch is empty,
not a speck of dust stands,
what need is there to regulate geng and jia?
Once you undertake it,
before your eyes, you will believe there is no dharma.

Within it, the revealed secret is hard to transmit,
nameless and unutterable,
its value lies in the heart’s comprehension.
Grasp it freely, and you will recognize it—
without crevice, how could a needle pass?
On the mountain of self and others,
in the sea of right and wrong,
one must further know life and death.
Nurture the formless,
and the numinous realm of forgetting form will unfold.

---

**Dispelling Doubts for the Assembly**
The swift path to immortality
lies in the mysterious pass—
one aperture, four directions, eight reaches.
First, instruct learners to establish resolve;
after awakening, it takes but an instant.
How laughable the deluded disciples,
who seek no teacher’s guidance,
clinging to side doors and methods.
Refining essence, refining qi—
in the end, all are mere detours.

Little do they know the great Dao is open and vast,
level and straight,
yet still requires a teacher’s revelation.
Once you grasp that good conduct leaves no tracks,
the mysterious female naturally opens and closes.
With a single thought of non-arising,
the valley spirit never dies,
and the ninefold work comes full circle.
Shedding the embryo, one returns—
striding through the Great Brahma Heaven.

---

**To the Tune of "Moon over the West River": To Daoist Pan**
True earth, true lead, true mercury,
primordial spirit, primordial qi, primordial essence.
When the three primordials unite, the elixir formula is complete—
this is the highest grade of the perfected.
In movement and stillness, numinous and unwavering,
completing the true form, round and bright.
Both form and spirit wondrous, delighting in non-arising,
one directly meets the August Void in its ultimate realm.

---

**To a Good Friend**
The supreme Dao originally has no words—
it depends entirely on unwavering resolve.
Keep the heart ever unobscured, delve to the root,
and a thousand pools reflect the same moon.
Once you grasp chasing wind and catching shadows,
you will know how to plant lotuses in fire.
Let the seas turn to mulberry fields—
only this remains fundamentally unchanged.

---

**To Zhou Shouzheng**
Seeing through the illusion of self and others,
what need is there to seek Buddha or immortals?
At all times and in all places, abide in meditation,
untainted by all illusory dust.
Whether in mountain seclusion or wild places,
or amid the bustle of city gates,
hold to the center, guard the three fields,
and in time, the spirit-pearl will appear.

---

**Refining Cinnabar: Chanting the Mysterious Female for the Assembly**
Few understand the mysterious female—
I tell you, gentlemen:
do not speak of north or south, east or west.
It is not in the four directions, nor above or below,
nor in the center.
Its opening and closing are wondrously inexhaustible,
the root and origin of heaven and earth.
In ceaseless generation and transformation, it exercises spiritual work.
The mechanism of movement and stillness never ceases,
vastly embracing and containing all.

---

**For the Assembly**
The supreme Dao is not transmitted—
it only requires a steadfast heart.
From beginning to end, hold fast to your resolve, never wavering.
Nine years, three years, ever constant—
this is the immortal.
True breathing naturally continuous,
the numinous ground level.
Hungry, eat; tired, sleep.
In summer, a single robe; in winter, a quilt—
beyond the mysterious, there is no mystery.

**Esoteric Sayings Beyond Teaching**

chunks.original_text: 佛书云：若人欲了知，三世一切佛，应观法界性，一切由心造。 是谓有造则有化，造化皆由心。 人皆谓造化万物者，造化之工也。 予独不然。 造化本无工，万物自造化也。 何以故？ 一切万物均有是心，既有是心，便有造化，岂非自造化耶？ 且如世间一切有形，形本无无而生有，是谓造； 有生便有灭。 有灭则复归於无，是谓化。 造造化化，物之常也。 一真之性本有，有而无象，故无造无化，道之常也。 人只知无造无化为不造化，殊不知有大造化存焉。 非明了者，其孰能知之。 明了之士，智慧圆通，则能万事见空，一心归寂，超然独存，故无造化也。 若不明了，外着於身心世事，内住於受想行识，所以随世变迁，随形生灭也。 目所见者，谓之色。 领纳在心，谓之受。 既受之在心，谓之想。 想而不已，至於作为，谓之行。 随行善恶各有报，谓之业识。 业识纷纷，输回之根本也，故不能出造化。 苟有不被幻缘缠缚，不被法尘染污，不被迷情障碍，不被爱欲苦恼，则能照见五蕴皆空。 五蕴既空，造化何有？ 此即是涅盘妙心也。 予谓造化由心，复何疑哉。 道书云：有无相生。 是谓无生有造也，有生无化也。 又云：致虚极，守静笃，万物并作，吾以观其复。 是谓观复知化也。 知化则不化，不化则安得有造？ 非洞观无碍者，孰能及此。 洞达之士，清静光明，故能勘破身心世事。 因虚幻中有有则为物，物极则返，返射复归虚幻也。 作是观者，则知无象之象，乃是实象； 养其无象，象故常存； 守其无体，体故全真。 至於纯纯全全，合乎大方，溟溟涬涬，合乎无伦，超出虚无之外，是谓无造化也。 执着之者，身心不定，念虑交攻，所以丧其无象，散其无体，故流浪生死，常沉苦海也。 苟有收拾身心，屏除念虑，内境勿令出，外境勿令入，内外清静，名为照了。 至於内忘其心，外忘其形，一真洞然，如太虚廓然，无碍造化，又何有焉。 儒书云：不忮不求，无咎无誉。 是谓不忮不求，则不受造也； 无咎无誉，则不受化也。 《易·系》云：远取诸物，近取诸身。 予谓远取诸物，则知万缘虚假； 近取诸身，则知五蕴皆空。 外屏万缘，内消五蕴，故能顺天施运，惧乐於天。 知物之始终，知幽明之故，知死生之说，穷理尽性，以至於命也。 乐天故不忧，尽性故不疑。 非致知者，孰能及此。 致知者诚明静定，故知生灭不停者，幻形也； 差别不平者，妄心也； 迁变不定者，时世也； 败坏不久者，事务也。 观练纯熟，是名圣功，一以贯之，故无造化。 若不致知，则不能格物，不能格物，则随物变迁，性命安在？ 苟有变动不居，周流六虚，故天地合乎我，万物备於我。 至於复见天心，万有归一无，则造化息矣。 譬如乾坤不变动； 日月不运行，六子何有？ 六子 不交重，阴阳不升降，万物何有？ 乾坤之体，纯一不杂，倒正不变，故无造化。 造无造之造，大造也。 化无化之化，大化也。 作是见者，故知世间万物皆是假合，阴阳运用无非幻妄，非天下之至变，其孰能与？ 於此观之，三教惟心也，造化由心也，出造化亦由心也。 学佛之要，在乎见性。 若欲见性，必先以决定之志，夺习俗之气，以严持之力，保洞然之明，然后照破种种空妄，心不着物，念不随情。
chunks.translated_text:
The Buddhist scriptures say: "If one wishes to fully understand all buddhas of the three times, one should contemplate the nature of the dharma-realm—all is created by the mind." This means that where there is creation, there is transformation, and both creation and transformation arise from the mind. People commonly say that the creator of the myriad things is the artisan of creation. I alone hold otherwise. Creation fundamentally has no artisan; the myriad things create and transform themselves. Why? Because all things possess this mind, and where this mind exists, there is creation and transformation—is this not self-creation and self-transformation?

Moreover, all forms in the world arise from non-being into being—this is called *creation*. Once born, they must perish; perishing, they return to non-being—this is called *transformation*. Creation and transformation in endless succession are the constant nature of things. The true nature of the One Reality is originally present, existing without form, and thus without creation or transformation—this is the constant Way. People only recognize the absence of creation and transformation as non-creation, failing to see that the great creation abides therein. Who but the enlightened can comprehend this?

The enlightened, with wisdom all-pervading, perceive all things as empty, return the mind to stillness, and abide in solitary transcendence—thus they are beyond creation and transformation. Those who lack enlightenment cling outwardly to body, mind, and worldly affairs, and inwardly dwell in sensation, perception, volition, and consciousness. Thus they follow the world’s vicissitudes and the cycle of birth and death.

What the eye sees is called *form*. Its reception in the mind is called *sensation*. Once received, it becomes *perception*. Perception unceasing leads to *volition*. Volition, whether good or evil, yields corresponding *karmic consciousness*. The ceaseless flux of karmic consciousness is the root of rebirth—thus one cannot escape creation and transformation. If one is not entangled by illusory conditions, not defiled by sense-dust, not obstructed by deluded emotions, not afflicted by craving and desire, then one can perceive the emptiness of the five aggregates. With the five aggregates empty, where is creation and transformation? This is the wondrous mind of nirvana.

I say that creation and transformation arise from the mind—what doubt remains?

The Daoist texts say: "Being and non-being produce each other." This means that non-being generates being—creation—and being generates non-being—transformation. They also say: "Attain utmost emptiness, guard absolute stillness; while the myriad things arise together, I observe their return." This is to observe the return and know transformation. Knowing transformation, one is no longer transformed; without transformation, how can there be creation? Who but one of unimpeded insight can attain this?

Those of penetrating vision, pure and luminous, can discern the illusory nature of body, mind, and worldly affairs. Within the illusory, what has form is called a thing; when things reach their extreme, they revert, reflecting back into the illusory. One who contemplates thus knows that the formless form is the true form. Nurturing the formless, form endures; preserving the formless, the body remains whole and true. In perfect purity and wholeness, one merges with the great square, vast and boundless, transcending the void—this is beyond creation and transformation.

Those who cling, unsettled in body and mind, assailed by thoughts, lose the formless and scatter the formless body, thus drifting in the cycle of birth and death, forever sinking in the sea of suffering. If one gathers in body and mind, dispels thoughts, prevents the inner from leaking outward and the outer from intruding inward, achieving inner and outer purity, this is called *illumination*. When one forgets the mind within and the body without, the One Reality shines clearly, like the vastness of empty space, unimpeded by creation and transformation—what then remains?

The Confucian texts say: "Neither envious nor covetous, free from blame and praise." This means that without envy or desire, one does not undergo creation; without blame or praise, one does not undergo transformation. The *Book of Changes* says: "Look afar to things, and near to oneself." I say: looking afar to things, one knows all conditions are illusory; looking near to oneself, one knows the five aggregates are empty. Externally, one screens off all conditions; internally, one dissolves the five aggregates—thus one accords with heaven’s workings and delights in the celestial.

Knowing the beginning and end of things, the causes of the hidden and manifest, the principles of life and death, one exhausts principle and fulfills nature, reaching destiny. Delighting in heaven, one is free from sorrow; fulfilling nature, one is free from doubt. Who but one who attains knowledge can reach this? One who attains knowledge is sincere, luminous, still, and settled—thus one knows that ceaseless birth and death belong to illusory form; inequality and discord arise from the deluded mind; impermanence and change pertain to the times; decay and ruin are the fate of affairs. Through refined observation and practice, this is called *sagehood*; unified in one principle, one is beyond creation and transformation.

Without attaining knowledge, one cannot investigate things; failing to investigate things, one is swayed by their changes—where then is nature and destiny? If one is not fixed but circulates through the six directions, then heaven and earth unite with me, and the myriad things are complete in me. When one again perceives the heart of heaven and all things return to the One Non-being, creation and transformation cease.

For example, if heaven and earth did not move, if the sun and moon did not revolve, what would become of the six lines? Without the six lines interacting and reconfiguring, without yin and yang ascending and descending, what would become of the myriad things? The essence of heaven and earth is pure and undivided, unchanging in inversion or uprightness—thus there is no creation or transformation. To create the creationless is the great creation; to transform the transformationless is the great transformation. One who sees thus knows that all things in the world are temporary combinations, and the workings of yin and yang are nothing but illusion. Who but the most profoundly adaptable can match this?

From this perspective, the Three Teachings are but the mind; creation arises from the mind, and transcending creation also arises from the mind. The essence of Buddhist practice lies in seeing one’s nature. To see one’s nature, one must first resolve with unwavering determination to overcome habitual energies, and with disciplined effort, preserve the luminous clarity within. Only then can one illuminate and break through all illusions, the mind not clinging to things, thoughts not following emotions.

chunks.original_text: 念是烦恼根，心是法尘种。 念起则一切烦恼起，念息则一切烦恼息； 心生则种种法生，心灭则种种法灭。 念起即止，皆由自心。 至於生灭灭已，寂灭为乐，是见性也。 今之学者不能见性者，为事理二障所碍也。 非大观则不能解理障，非大止则不能除事障。 大观谓智断也，大止谓力制也。 智断纯孰，则理理皆空； 力制纯孰，则事事皆空。 了三空之大空，知一真之至真，此大观之至也。 即时身心世事、念虑情识，一齐都止，此大止之至也。 非上上智，其孰能与於此。 学道在乎存性。 若欲存性，必先以慧剑斩群魔，火符消六欲。 次以定力忘情绝虑，释累清心，至於心清累释、虑绝情忘，是谓存性。 真性既存，则无造化。 今之学者，为情识之所夺也。 欲去情识，先除生灭心。 心无生灭，身无生灭，定矣。 去生灭心，必自无念之积习纯熟，足可致无梦； 无念之静定纯熟，足可致无生。 无梦乃见在之大事也，无念乃末后之大事也。 无生则不造，无梦财不化，不造不化，即不生不灭也。 非高上之士，其孰能与於此。 儒学之要，在乎尽性。 若欲尽性，在明明德，在止於至善。 知止而后有定，有定则能忘物我。 艮卦辞云：艮其背，不获其身，行其庭，不见其人，无咎。 艮其背，忘其心也。 不获其身，忘我也。 行其庭不见其人，忘物也。 三者既忘，何咎之有？ 此知止之至也。 知止故能忘物我而全天理，是谓尽性也。 今人不能尽性者，为身心之累也。 既有累便有室碍，必以刚断果决。 刚断故能忘物，果决故能忘我，物我两忘，尽性至命定矣。 非神德圣功，其孰能与於此。 予见世人多以此身为有我，其不思之甚也。 且如此身因造而有，未造之前有象乎？ 有名乎？ 有我乎？ 既化之后有象乎？ 有名乎？ 有我乎？ 前后两既俱无，安得中间偏执有我耶。 殊不知身心世事本来虚妄，三世推求了不可得。 过去杳然何在，只今念念变迁，未来决定如是。 历劫以来大梦幻中，坚执妄缘，结成输回种子，是以出生入死，无有了期。 若复有 人於此梦幻境中，证明了知而善消遣，岂非至人乎。 予一日举此公案，令门人参。 二三子稍合符节，故作此书以赠之，以心传心。 若能直下承当，潜通默会，即时知止，不谋其前，不虑其后，不恋只今，三者混成，得大自在。 徜徉乎大寂灭之海，逍逼乎无何有之乡，游泳乎自得之场。 至此方知，造化於此何预焉。 虽然，更有向上事在。 且道唤甚么做向上事？ 咦，掀翻无字脚，粉碎太虚空，方为了事汉。 秘之秘之。 绝学无忧篇并叙 所为绝学者，非不学也。 若以不学为绝学，则罔无所知，只同常流也。 此所谓绝学者，博学而至於绝学也。 盖由世人多学为奇特，转学转不会也。 圣人云：其出弥远，其知弥少。 又云：多则惑，少则得。 正谓此也。 前儒云：有为终日息，无为便不息。 即此意也。 故作是篇以证之，使学徒不为声闻缘觉、学解见知所累也。 日用总玄玄，时人识未全。 当推心上好，放下口头禅。 法法非空法，传传是妄传。 不曾修福始，焉能有祸先。 不益便无损，不变岂能迁。 不垢亦不净，无缺亦无圆。 莫着嗔和喜，何愁迍与邅。 不作善因果，那得恶因缘。 不闻兴废事，名利不相牵。 精粗无忧恶，妍丑不憎怜。
chunks.translated_text:
Thought is the root of affliction; the mind is the seed of dharmic dust. When thought arises, all afflictions arise; when thought ceases, all afflictions cease. When the mind arises, all dharmas arise; when the mind is extinguished, all dharmas are extinguished. The arising and cessation of thought depend entirely on one’s own mind. When birth-and-death are extinguished, and quiescent extinction becomes bliss, this is seeing one’s nature.

Today’s learners fail to see their nature because they are obstructed by the two hindrances of principle and phenomena. Without great insight, one cannot dissolve the hindrance of principle; without great cessation, one cannot remove the hindrance of phenomena. Great insight means wisdom and severance; great cessation means power and restraint. When wisdom and severance are pure and mature, all principles become empty; when power and restraint are pure and mature, all phenomena become empty. Comprehending the great emptiness of the three emptinesses, and knowing the supreme truth of the one true reality—this is the ultimate of great insight. At that moment, body, mind, worldly affairs, thoughts, emotions, and consciousness all cease together—this is the ultimate of great cessation. Without the highest wisdom, who can attain this?

The essence of Daoist practice lies in preserving one’s nature. To preserve one’s nature, one must first wield the sword of wisdom to slay the hordes of demons and use the fire talisman to dissolve the six desires. Next, with the power of concentration, one forgets emotions and cuts off thoughts, releases burdens and purifies the mind. When the mind is purified, burdens are released, thoughts are cut off, and emotions are forgotten—this is preserving one’s nature. Once true nature is preserved, there is no creation. Today’s learners are seized by emotions and consciousness. To eliminate emotions and consciousness, one must first remove the mind of birth-and-death. When the mind is free from birth-and-death, the body is free from birth-and-death—this is stability. To remove the mind of birth-and-death, one must cultivate the habit of no-thought until it is pure and mature, sufficient to attain dreamlessness. When the stillness and stability of no-thought are pure and mature, one can attain birthlessness. Dreamlessness is the great matter of the present; no-thought is the great matter of the end. Birthlessness means no creation; dreamlessness means no transformation. Without creation or transformation, there is no birth or death. Without the most exalted of beings, who can attain this?

The essence of Confucian learning lies in fully realizing one’s nature. To fully realize one’s nature, one must illuminate the luminous virtue and rest at the highest good. Knowing where to rest, one then attains stability; with stability, one can forget both self and others. The *Yijing* says in the *Gen* hexagram: *"Stopping at the back, one does not obtain the body; walking in the courtyard, one does not see others—no blame."* Stopping at the back means forgetting the mind; not obtaining the body means forgetting the self; walking in the courtyard without seeing others means forgetting things. When these three are forgotten, what blame can there be? This is the ultimate of knowing where to rest. Knowing where to rest, one can forget self and others and fully embody heavenly principle—this is fully realizing one’s nature.

Today’s people cannot fully realize their nature because they are burdened by body and mind. With burdens come obstructions; one must be resolute and decisive. Resoluteness enables one to forget things; decisiveness enables one to forget the self. When both self and things are forgotten, one fully realizes one’s nature and stabilizes one’s destiny. Without divine virtue and sagely merit, who can attain this?

I see that most people regard this body as having a self—how profoundly they fail to reflect! This body exists because of creation; before creation, was there form? Was there name? Was there a self? After transformation, will there be form? Name? A self? Both before and after, there is nothing—how can one stubbornly cling to a self in the middle? They do not realize that body, mind, and worldly affairs are fundamentally illusory; tracing them through the three times, nothing can be found. The past is utterly gone—where is it? The present changes with every thought. The future will certainly be the same. Through kalpas of time, in this great dream and illusion, stubbornly clinging to false conditions, one accumulates the seeds of samsara, thus entering birth and death without end.

If there is someone in this dreamlike realm who awakens, understands, and skillfully navigates it, is this not a supreme person? One day, I presented this koan to my disciples for contemplation. Two or three of them somewhat grasped its essence, so I wrote this text to bestow upon them, transmitting mind with mind. If one can directly accept and silently comprehend it, instantly knowing where to rest, without scheming for the future or worrying about the past, without clinging to the present—when these three merge into one, one attains great freedom. Roaming in the ocean of great quiescent extinction, wandering in the realm of nothingness, swimming in the field of self-attainment—only then does one realize that creation has nothing to do with this.

Yet there is still something beyond. What is this "something beyond"? Hmph! Overturn the foot of the wordless, shatter the great void—only then is one a true man of the Way. Keep this secret, keep it secret.

**On the "No-Learning Without Worry" and Its Preface**

What is called "no-learning" is not non-learning. If one takes non-learning as no-learning, one remains ignorant and indistinguishable from the common crowd. This so-called no-learning is the culmination of extensive learning. Most people learn to be extraordinary, but the more they learn, the less they understand. The sage said: *"The farther one goes, the less one knows."* And also: *"Much leads to confusion; little leads to attainment."* This is precisely the point. A former Confucian said: *"With effort, one rests all day; without effort, one does not rest."* This is the same idea. Thus, I write this piece to demonstrate it, so that learners are not burdened by the hearer and solitary realizer vehicles, or by intellectual understanding and discriminative knowledge.

In daily life, all is profoundly mysterious,
Yet people do not fully recognize it.
One should pursue what the heart truly loves,
And let go of mere verbal Zen.

Every dharma is not an empty dharma;
Every transmission is a false transmission.
Without cultivating blessings first,
How can misfortune arise prematurely?

Without gain, there is no loss;
Without change, how can there be alteration?
Without defilement, there is no purity;
Without lack, there is no completeness.

Do not cling to anger or joy;
Why worry about adversity or obstruction?
Without doing good as cause,
How can evil conditions arise?

Unconcerned with rise and fall,
Name and profit do not entangle.
Coarse and fine incur no worry or aversion;
Beauty and ugliness evoke no hatred or love.
chunks.overlap_context: his perspective, the Three Teachings are but the mind; creation arises from the mind, and transcending creation also arises from the mind. The essence of Buddhist practice lies in seeing one’s nature. To see one’s nature, one must first resolve with unwavering determination to overcome habitual energies, and with disciplined effort, preserve the luminous clarity within. Only then can one illuminate and break through all illusions, the mind not clinging to things, thoughts not following emotions.

chunks.original_text: 不偿欢喜债，都无恩怨缠。 打开人我网，跳出是非圈。 清虚不好古，恬澹倦希贤。 休思今世后，放下未生前。 从他佛是佛，任伊仙是仙。 既无尘俗累，何忧业火煎。 有无俱不立，虚实任相连。 都缘无取舍，自然无过愆。 来去浑忘却，死生何预焉。 居止无余欠，随处任方圆。 饥来一椀饭，渴则半瓯泉。 兴来自消遣，困来且打眠。 达者明此义，休寻天外天。 见前赤洒洒，末后亮娟娟。 中和集卷之六竟 #1密：原本作『令』，於义难解。 据朱孝臧《疆村业书》所用元刊本改。
chunks.translated_text:
Unburdened by debts of joy,
No entanglements of gratitude or resentment remain.
Breaking free from the net of self and others,
Leaping beyond the circle of right and wrong.

In clarity and emptiness, antiquity holds no charm;
In tranquility and simplicity, the pursuit of worthies wearies.
Cease pondering the life to come,
Release the thoughts of what precedes birth.

Let Buddhas be Buddhas,
Let immortals be immortals.
Freed from the dust of worldly burdens,
Why fear the searing flames of karma?

Neither existence nor nonexistence is established;
Vacuity and reality intertwine as they will.
All arises from non-grasping, non-rejecting—
Naturally, no faults or transgressions arise.

Coming and going are wholly forgotten;
What concern is there for death or life?
Dwelling leaves no lack or excess,
Everywhere adapting to square or round.

Hunger comes—take a bowl of rice;
Thirst arises—drink half a cup of spring water.
When inclined, amuse yourself;
When weary, sleep.

The enlightened understand this principle—
Cease seeking heavens beyond heavens.
Before the eyes, all is radiant and clear;
In the end, all shines bright and pure.

*Middle Harmony Collection, Scroll Six, Concluded*
